  X \to \Im X


is a 1-epimorphism. This is equivalent to the essentially unique morphism X‚Üí*X \to * to the terminal object being a formally smooth morphism.
The concept of super smooth ‚àû\infty-groupoid or super smooth geometric homotopy type is the combination of super ‚àû-groupoid and smooth ‚àû-groupoid. The cohesive (‚àû,1)-topos of smooth super-‚àû\infty-groupoids is a context that realizes higher supergeometry.
Super smooth ‚àû\infty-groupoids include supermanifolds, super Lie groups and their deloopings etc. Under Lie differentiation these map to super L-‚àû algebras.
We consider one of at least two possible definitions, that differ (only) in some fine technical detail. The other is at smooth super infinity-groupoid.

Definition
Write

SuperPoint‚âîWAlg super opSuperPoint \coloneqq WAlg_{super}^{op} for the category of superpoints, by which we here mean the formal duals to commutative superalgebras which are super-Weil algebras.

Proof
All the sites are ‚àû-cohesive sites, which gives that we have an cohesive (infinity,1)-topos. The composite inclusion on the right is an ‚àû-cohesive neighbourhood site, whence the inclusion Smooth‚àûGpd‚Ü™SuperFormalSmooth‚àûGrpdSmooth\infty Gpd\hookrightarrow SuperFormalSmooth\infty Grpd exhibits differential cohesion.
With this the rightmost adjoint quadruple gives the Aufhebung of ‚Ñú‚ä£‚Ñë\Re \dashv \Im by ‚áù‚ä£Rh\rightsquigarrow \dashv Rh and the further opposition ‚áâ‚ä£‚áù\rightrightarrows \dashv \rightsquigarrow.

On super smooth infinity-groupoids there is a modal operator (‚àí)‚áù\stackrel{\rightsquigarrow}{(-)} which projects onto the bosonic components of the supergeometry. On formal dual superalgebras this is given by passing to the body. In terms of physical fields this is the projection onto boson fields, which are hence the modal types of ‚áù\rightsquigarrow, and so it makes sense to speak of the bosonic modality.
This has a left adjoint ‚áâ\rightrightarrows (which on superalgebras passes to the even-graded sub-algebra) and hence together these form an adjoint modality which may be thought of as characterizing the supergeometry. See at super smooth infinity-groupoid ‚Äì Cohesion. With ‚áâ\rightrightarrows being opposite to ‚áù\rightsquigarrow thereby, it makes sense to call it the fermionic modality.
Notice that the fermionic currents in physics (e.g. the electron density current) are indeed fermionic bilinears, i.e. are indeed in the even subalgebras of the underlying superalgebra.

  }


The modal objects for ‚áù\rightsquigarrow are the bosonic objects.
The right adjoint of the bosonic modality is the rheonomy modality.

Since the crucial extra structures carried by an orbifold are


geometric structure (e.g. topological, algebro-geometric, differential-geometric, super-geometric, etc.)


singularities


the cohomology of orbifolds should be such as to provide invariants which are sensitive not just to the underlying plain homotopy type of an orbifold (its shape) but also to this extra structure. This means that orbifold cohomology should, respectively, unify


geometric cohomology (e.g. sheaf hypercohomology, differential cohomology, etc.)


equivariant cohomology in its fine form of Bredon cohomology


in the sense that geometric cohomology is recovered away from the orbifold singularities and equivariant cohomology is recovered right at the singularities, while globally orbifold cohomology provides a unification of these two aspects.
Since any concept of cohomology (as discussed there) is effectively equivalent to the choice of ambient (‚àû,1)-topos, the question of defining orbifold cohomology is closely related to the question of how exactly to define the (‚àû,1)-category of orbifolds (usually a (2,1)-category) in the first place. This question is notoriously more subtle than the simple intuitive idea of orbifolds might suggest, as witnessed by the convoluted history of the concept (see e.g. Lerman 08, Introduction).

Deficiency of orbifolds as geometric groupoids
A proposal popular among Lie theorists (Moerdijk-Pronk 97) is to regard an orbifold with local charts U i‚ààG iActionsU_i \in G_i Actions (actions of some group on some local model space) as the geometric stack obtained by gluing the corresponding homotopy quotients/quotient stacks U i‚´ΩG iU_i \!\sslash \!G_i. If H\mathbf{H} is the ambient cohesive (‚àû,1)-topos in which this takes place (for instance H=\mathbf{H} =  Smooth‚àûGroupoids, SuperFormalSmooth‚àûGroupoids, etc.) and if G‚ààGrp‚Ü™DiscGrp(H)G \in Grp \overset{Disc}{\hookrightarrow} Grp(\mathbf{H}) is a discrete group in which all the isotropy groups of the orbifold are contained, this gives an object
(ùí≥ ‚Üì faith BG faith)‚àà(H /BG) ‚â§0‚Ü™H /BG
  \left(
  \array{
    \mathcal{X}
    \\
    \downarrow^{\mathrlap{faith}}
    \\
    \mathbf{B}G
  }
  \phantom{{}^{faith}}
  \right)
  \;\in\;
  \left( 
    \mathbf{H}_{/\mathbf{B}G}
  \right)_{\leq 0}
  \hookrightarrow
  \mathbf{H}_{/\mathbf{B}G}


in the slice (‚àû,1)-topos over the delooping BG=*‚´ΩG\mathbf{B}G = \ast \sslash G of GG, which is still a 0-truncated object, reflecting that as a functor of groupoids the morphism ùí≥‚ÜíBG\mathcal{X} \to \mathbf{B}G is a faithful functor.
Accordingly, if this is ‚Äì or were ‚Äì the correct formalization of the nature of orbifolds ùí≥\mathcal{X}, then the corresponding orbifold cohomology has coefficients given by objects ùíú‚ààH /BG\mathcal{A} \in \mathbf{H}_{/\mathbf{B}G} and cohomology sets being the connected components of the (‚àû,1)-categorical hom-spaces

This concept of orbifold cohomology does fully reflect the geometric nature of orbifolds. It also reflects some equivariance aspect. For example if ùí≥=*‚´ΩG\mathcal{X} = \ast \sslash G is the one-point orbifold with singularity given by a finite group GG, and if V‚ààGRepresentationsV \in G Representations is a linear representation, with K(V,n)‚´ΩG‚àà‚àûGroupoids /BG‚Ü™DiscH /BGK(V,n)\sslash G \in \infty Groupoids_{/\mathbf{B}G} \overset{Disc}{\hookrightarrow} \mathbf{H}_{/\mathbf{B}G} its Eilenberg-MacLane space, then

is the group cohomology of GG with coefficients in VV.
However, this definition does not reflect Bredon-equivariant cohomology around the orbifold singularities. Instead, it really given (geometric/stacky refinement) of cohomology with local coefficients.
\,
Lift of orbifolds to singular-cohesive homotopy theory
Hence the proposal of Moerdijk-Pronk 97, that an orbifold should be regarded as a certain geometric stack, is missing something. It was briefly suggested in Schwede 17, Introduction, Schwede 18, p. ix-x that the missing aspect is provided by global equivariant homotopy theory, but details seem to have been left open.
Here we discuss how to define the required orbifold cohomology in detail and in general. We combine the differential cohesion for the geometric aspect with the cohesion of global equivariant homotopy theory that was observed and highlighted in Rezk 14.
The following may serve as intuition for the issue with the nature of orbifolds:
Envision the picture of an orbifold singularity and hold a mathemagical magnifying glass over the singular point. Under this magnification you can see resolved the singular point as a fuzzy fattened point, to be called ùîπG\mathbb{B}G.
Removing the magnifying glass, what one sees with the bare eye depends on how one squints:


The physicist says that what he sees is a singular point, but a point after all. This is the plain quotient *=*/G\ast = \ast / G.


The Lie geometer says that what she sees is a point transforming under the GG-action that fixes it, hence the homotopy quotient groupoid BG=*‚´ΩG\mathbf{B}G =\ast \sslash G.


These are two opposite extreme aspects of the orbifold singularity ùîπG\mathbb{B}G, but the orbifold singularity itself is more than both of these aspects. The real nature of an orbifold singularity is in fact a point, not a big classifying space BG\mathbf{B} G (recall that already B‚Ñ§ 2=‚ÑùP ‚àû\mathbf{B}\mathbb{Z}_2 = \mathbb{R}P^\infty), but it is a point that also remembers the group action, for that characterizes how the singularity is being singular:
  orbifold singularityùîπG   <‚Üô Aopposite extremeaspects of orbifold singularity ‚Üò ‚äÇ plain quotient*=*/G    homotopy quotientBG=*‚´ΩG
   \array{
       && 
       { \text{orbifold singularity} \atop {\mathbb{B}G} }
      \\
      & {}^{\mathllap{\boxed{\lt}}}\swarrow 
      & 
       {{\phantom{A}} \atop {  \text{opposite extreme} \atop \text{aspects of orbifold singularity} }} & \searrow^{\mathrlap{ \boxed{\subset} }}
     \\
     { \text{plain quotient} \atop {\ast = \ast/G} }
     &&
     &&
     { \text{homotopy quotient} \atop { \mathbf{B}G = \ast \sslash G } }

A smooth algebra or C ‚àûC^\infty-ring is an algebra AA over the reals ‚Ñù\mathbb{R} for which not only the product operation ‚ãÖ:‚Ñù√ó‚Ñù‚Üí‚Ñù\cdot : \mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R} lifts to the algebra product A√óA‚ÜíAA \times A \to A, but for which every smooth map f:‚Ñù n‚Üí‚Ñù mf : \mathbb{R}^n \to \mathbb{R}^m (morphism in Diff) lifts to a map A(f):A n‚ÜíA mA(f) : A^n \to A^m in a compatible way.
In short this means that AA is


a product-preserving co-presheaf on CartSp;


equivalently: an algebra for the Lawvere theory CartSp;


The smoothness of such C ‚àûC^\infty-rings is witnessed by the fact that this Lawvere theory is even a Fermat theory.
The opposite category of the category of C ‚àûC^\infty-rings is the category of smooth loci. This and its subcategories play a major role as sites for categories of sheaves that serve as models for synthetic differential geometry.
Limits and colimits

Proposition
All limits and all directed colimits in C ‚àûRingC^\infty Ring are computed objectwise in [CartSp,Set][CartSp,Set] as limits in Set.


Proof
As discussed at limits and colimits by example, all limits and colimits in [CartSp,Set][CartSp,Set] are computed objectwise, so the remaining question is if they preserve the property of functors CartSp‚ÜíSetCartSp \to Set to preserved products. The claim follows from the observation that limits and directed colimits do commute with products.

See also MSIA, p. 22.

in the category of TT-algebras, where Œº T:TT‚ÜíT\mu_T: T T \to T is the monad multiplication. Points of smooth loci
An ‚Ñù\mathbb{R}-point of a C ‚àûC^\infty-ring CC is a point *‚ÜíùïÉ(C)* \to \mathbb{L}(C) of the corresponding smooth locus, i.e. a morphism C‚Üí‚Ñù‚âÖC ‚àû(*)C \to \mathbb{R} \cong C^\infty(*).

Proposition
Points of a C ‚àûC^\infty-ring are in bijection with points of the underlying ‚Ñù\mathbb{R}-algebra U(C)U(C), i.e. with ordinary ‚Ñù\mathbb{R}-algebra morphisms U(C)‚Üí‚ÑùU(C) \to \mathbb{R}.

By the properties of C ‚àû(X)C^\infty(X) for XX a smooth manifold discussed below, the ‚Ñù\mathbb{R}-points of C ‚àû(X)C^\infty(X) are precisely the ordinary points of the manifold XX.

Turning this inclusion into an equivalence is usually called a completion of the algebraic tensor product. Therefore we see:

The smooth tensor product is automatically the completed tensor product.

In summary this yields the following characterization of smooth function algebras on manifolds.

A smooth locus is the formal dual of a finitely generated smooth algebra (or C ‚àûC^\infty-ring):
a space that behaves as if its algebra of functions is a finitely generated smooth algebra.
Given that a smooth algebra is a smooth refinement of an ordinary ring with a morphism from ‚Ñù\mathbb{R}, a smooth locus is the analog in well-adapted models for synthetic differential geometry for what in algebraic geometry is an affine variety over ‚Ñù\mathbb{R}.
A finitely generated smooth algebra is one of the form C ‚àû(‚Ñù n)/JC^\infty(\mathbb{R}^n)/J, for JJ an ideal of the ordinary underlying algebra.
Write C ‚àûRing finC^\infty Ring^{fin} for the category of finitely generated smooth algebras.
Then the opposite category ùïÉ:=(C ‚àûRing fin) op\mathbb{L} := (C^\infty Ring^{fin})^{op} is the category of smooth loci.

Proposition
The Tietze extension theorem holds in ùïÉ\mathbb{L}: RR-valued functions on closed subobjects in ùïÉ\mathbb{L} have an extension.

A ‚ÄòFermat theory‚Äô is a Lawvere theory that extends the usual theory of commutative rings by permitting differentiation.
The term Fermat theory seems to have been introduced in (Kock 09) based on (Dubuc-Kock 84). But as the name suggests, it has its roots in an old observation of Fermat. Namely: if f:‚Ñù‚ü∂‚Ñùf \;\colon\; \mathbb{R} \longrightarrow \mathbb{R} is a polynomial function, then
f(x+y)=f(x)+yfÀú(x,y)f (x+y) = f(x) + y \tilde{f}(x,y) 
for a unique polynomial function fÀú:‚Ñù 2‚Üí‚Ñù\tilde{f} \colon \mathbb{R}^2 \to \mathbb{R}. Clearly
fÀú(x,y)=f(x+y)‚àíf(x)y \tilde{f}(x,y) = \frac{f(x+y) - f(x)}{y} 
for y‚â†0y \ne 0, but the interesting thing is that
fÀú(x,0)=f‚Ä≤(x)\tilde{f}(x,0) = f'(x)
So, the function fÀú\tilde{f} knows about the derivative of ff! (This can be done for polynomials over any commutative ring, although Fermat wasn't working in that generality.)
Later Jacques Hadamard generalized this observation from a polynomial function ff to a continuously differentiable function ff, where now fÀú\tilde{f} is unique if required to be continuous. This is the statement of the Hadamard lemma. (For a merely differentiable function ff, require fÀú\tilde{f} to be continuous in yy alone.) The function fÀú\tilde{f} is thus called a Hadamard quotient. If fÀú\tilde{f} is to be the same class of function as ff, then we need smooth functions, and that will be our motivating context from now on.
If we take fÀú(x,0)=f‚Ä≤(x)\tilde{f}(x,0) = f'(x) as a definition of the derivative, we can derive many of the basic rules for derivatives from the formula
f(x+y)=f(x)+yfÀú(x,y)f(x+y) = f(x) + y \tilde{f}(x,y) 
using just algebra ‚Äî no limits! As an exercise, the reader should check these rules:
(f+g)‚Ä≤=f‚Ä≤+g‚Ä≤(f + g)' = f' + g'
(fg)‚Ä≤=f‚Ä≤g+fg‚Ä≤(f g)' = f' g + f g' 
(f‚àòg)‚Ä≤=(f‚Ä≤‚àòg)g‚Ä≤(f \circ g)' = (f' \circ g) g' 
These ideas continue to work if ff is a smooth function from ‚Ñù n\mathbb{R}^n to ‚Ñù\mathbb{R}; focussing on one variable and treating the others as parameter?s, we have partial differentiation.
The above observations suggest defining the following kind of Lawvere theory. A Fermat theory is an extension of the algebraic theory of commutative rings, such that for any (n+1)(n+1)-ary operation ff there is a unique (n+2)(n+2)-ary operation fÀú\tilde{f} such that
f(x+y,z‚Üí)=f(x,z‚Üí)+yfÀú(x,y,z‚Üí) f(x + y, \vec{z}) =
f(x, \vec{z}) + y \tilde{f}(x,y,\vec{z})

where z‚Üí\vec{z} is a list of nn variables which act as parameters. (Here we are abusing language by writing the operations ff and fÀú\tilde{f} as if they were functions, to avoid unintuitive commutative diagrams.)
The Cahier topos is a cohesive topos that constitutes a well-adapted model for synthetic differential geometry (a ‚Äúsmooth topos‚Äù).
It is the sheaf topos on the site FormalCartSp of infinitesimally thickened Cartesian spaces.

Definition
Let FormalCartSp be the full subcategory of the category of smooth loci on those of the form
‚Ñù n√ó‚ÑìW,
  \mathbb{R}^n \times \ell W
  \,,


consisting of a product of a Cartesian space with an infinitesimally thickened point, i.e. a formal dual of a Weil algebra .
Dually, the opposite category is the full subcategory FormalCartSp op‚Ü™SmoothAlgFormalCartSp^{op} \hookrightarrow SmoothAlg of smooth algebras on those of the form
C ‚àû(‚Ñù k√ó‚ÑìW)=C ‚àû(‚Ñù k)‚äóW.
  C^\infty( \mathbb{R}^k \times \ell W)
  = 
  C^\infty(\mathbb{R}^k) \otimes W
  \,.


This appears for instance in Kock Reyes (1).

Definition
Define a structure of a site on FormalCartSp by declaring a covering family to be a family of the form
{U i√ó‚ÑìW‚Üíp i√óIdU√ó‚ÑìW}
  \{
    U_i \times \ell W \stackrel{p_i \times Id}{\to} U \times \ell W
  \}


where {U i‚Üíp iU}\{U_i \stackrel{p_i}{\to} U\} is an open cover of the Cartesian space UU by Cartesian spaces U iU_i.

This appears as Kock (5.1).

Definition
The Cahiers topos ùíûùíØ\mathcal{CT} is the category of sheaves on this site:
ùíûùíØ:=Sh(FormalCartSp).
  \mathcal{CT} := Sh(FormalCartSp)  
  \,.


This site of definition appears in Kock, Reyes. The original definition is due to Dubuc 79
Synthetic differential geometry

The Cahiers topos is a well-adapted model for synthetic differential geometry.

This is due to Dubuc 79.

Convenient vector spaces

Proposition
The category of convenient vector spaces with smooth functions between them embeds as a full subcategory into the Cahiers topos.
The embedding is given by sending a convenient vector space VV to the sheaf given by
V:‚Ñù k√ó‚ÑìW‚Ü¶C ‚àû(‚Ñù k,V)‚äóW.
  V
  : 
  \mathbb{R}^k \times \ell W
  \mapsto 
  C^\infty(\mathbb{R}^k, V) \otimes W
  \,.


This result was announced in Kock. See the corrected proof in (KockReyes).

Remark
Together with prop.  this means that the differential geometry on convenient vector spaces may be treated synthetically in the Cahiers topos.

Synthetic tangent spaces
We discuss here induced synthetic tangent spaces of smooth spaces in the sense of diffeological spaces and more general sheaves on the site of smooth manifolds after their canonical embedding into the Cahiers topos.

for the full subcategory on the Cartesian spaces ‚Ñù n\mathbb{R}^n (n‚àà‚Ñïn \in \mathbb{N}). Write

We regard CartSp as a site by equipping it with the good open cover coverage. We regard InfThPointInfThPoint as equipped with the trivial coverage and CartSp synthdiffCartSp_{synthdiff} as equipped with the induced product coverage.
The sheaf topos Sh(CartSp)Sh(CartSp) is that of smooth spaces. The sheaf topos Sh(CartSp synthdiff)Sh(CartSp_{synthdiff}) is the Cahier topos.

for the infinitesimal interval, the smooth locus dual to the smooth algebra ‚Äúof dual numbers‚Äù.

Proposition

‚Ñì(W)‚Üíi !X
  \ell(W) \to i_! X

‚Ñì(W)‚Üí‚Ñù n‚ÜíX
  \ell(W) \to \mathbb{R}^n \to X


consisting of a morphism in CartSp synthCartSp_{synth} on the left and a morphism in Sh(CartSp)Sh(CartSp) on the right (which live in different categories and hence are not composable, but usefully written in juxtaposition anyway).   ‚Ñù n  ‚Üó  ‚Üò ‚Ñì(W)  ‚Üì œï  X  ‚Üò  ‚Üó   ‚Ñù n‚Ä≤
  \array{
    && \mathbb{R}^n
    \\
    & \nearrow & & \searrow
    \\
    \ell(W) && \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\phi}} && X
    \\
    & \searrow && \nearrow
    \\
    && \mathbb{R}^{n'}
  }


the left triangle commutes in CartSp synthdiffCartSp_{synthdiff} and the right one in Sh(CartSp)Sh(CartSp).


Proof
By general properties of left adjoints of functors of presheaves, i !Xi_! X is the left Kan extension of the presheaf XX along ii. By the Yoneda lemma and the coend formula for these (as discussed there), we have that the set of maps ‚Ñì(W)‚Üíi !X\ell(W) \to i_! X is naturally identified with

  (i_! X)(\ell(W))
  =
  (Lan_i X)(\ell(W))
  =
  \int^{\mathbb{R}^n \in CartSp}
  Hom_{CartSp_{synthdiff}}(\ell(W), \mathbb{R}^n)
  \times 
  X(\mathbb{R}^n)
  \,.


Unwinding the definition of this coend as a coequalizer yields the above description of equivalence classes.

A smooth ‚àû\infty-groupoid is an ‚àû-groupoid equipped with cohesion in the form of smooth structure. Examples include smooth manifolds, Lie groups, Lie groupoids and generally Lie infinity-groupoids, but also for instance moduli spaces of differential forms, moduli stacks of principal connections and generally of cocycles in differential cohomology.
The (‚àû,1)-topos Smooth‚àûGrpdSmooth \infty Grpd of all smooth ‚àû\infty-groupoids is a cohesive (‚àû,1)-topos. It realizes a higher geometry version of differential geometry.
Many properties of smooth ‚àû\infty-groupoids are inherited from the underlying Euclidean-topological ‚àû-groupoids. See ETop‚àûGrpd for more.
There is a refinement of smooth ‚àû\infty-groupoids to synthetic differential ‚àû-groupoids. See SynthDiff‚àûGrpd for more on that.

Definition
For XX a smooth manifold, say an open cover {U i‚ÜíX}\{U_i \to X\} is a differentiably good open cover if each non-empty finite intersection of the U iU_i is diffeomorphic to a Cartesian space.


Proposition
Every paracompact smooth manifold admits a differentiably good open cover.


Proof
This is mathematical folklore. A detailed proof is given at good open cover.


Definition
Let SmoothMfd be the large site of paracompact smooth manifolds with smooth functions between them and equipped with the coverage of differentiably good open covers.



Proposition
This does indeed define a coverage. The Grothendieck topology that is generated from it is the standard open cover topology.



Proof
For {U i‚ÜíX}\{U_i \to X\} any open cover of a paracompact manifold also ‚àê iU i\coprod_i U_i is paracompact. Hence we may find a differentiably good open cover {K j‚Üí‚àê iU i}\{K_j \to \coprod_i U_i\}. This is then a refinement of the original open cover of XX.


Definition
Let CartSp smooth{}_{smooth} be the site of Cartesian spaces with smooth functions between them and equipped with the coverage of differentiably good open covers.


Definition
The (‚àû,1)-topos of smooth ‚àû\infty-groupoids is the (‚àû,1)-category of (‚àû,1)-sheaves on CartSp smooth{}_{smooth}:

A formal smooth ‚àû\infty-groupoid is an ‚àû-groupoid equipped with a cohesive structure that subsumes that of smooth ‚àû-groupoids as well as of infinitesimal ‚àû\infty-groupoids ‚Äì ‚àû-Lie algebroids, hence equipped with ‚Äúdifferential cohesion‚Äù.

The concept of super smooth ‚àû\infty-groupoid or super smooth geometric homotopy type is the combination of super ‚àû-groupoid and smooth ‚àû-groupoid. The cohesive (‚àû,1)-topos of smooth super-‚àû\infty-groupoids is a context that realizes higher supergeometry.
Super smooth ‚àû\infty-groupoids include supermanifolds, super Lie groups and their deloopings etc. Under Lie differentiation these map to super L-‚àû algebras.
We consider one of at least two possible definitions, that differ (only) in some fine technical detail. The other is at smooth super infinity-groupoid.

Definition
Write


CartSp for the site of Cartesian spaces;


InfPoint‚âîWAlg opInfPoint \coloneqq WAlg^{op} for the category of first-order infinitesimally thickened points (i.e. the formal duals of commutative algebras over the real numbers of the form ‚Ñù‚äïV\mathbb{R}\oplus V with VV a finite-dimensional square-0 nilpotent ideal).


SuperPoint‚âîWAlg super opSuperPoint \coloneqq WAlg_{super}^{op} for the category of superpoints, by which we here mean the formal duals to commutative superalgebras which are super-Weil algebras.


There are then ‚Äúsemidirect product‚Äù sites CartSp‚ãäInfinPointCartSp \rtimes InfinPoint and CartSp‚ãäSuperPointCartSp \rtimes SuperPoint (whose objects are Cartesian products of the given form inside synthetic differential supergeometry and whose morphisms are all morphisms in that context (not just the product morphisms)).

All the sites are ‚àû-cohesive sites, which gives that we have an cohesive (infinity,1)-topos. With this the rightmost adjoint quadruple gives the Aufhebung of ‚Ñú‚ä£‚Ñë\Re \dashv \Im by ‚áù‚ä£Rh\rightsquigarrow \dashv Rh and the further opposition ‚áâ‚ä£‚áù\rightrightarrows \dashv \rightsquigarrow.

Higher Lie theory is the refinement of Lie theory to higher geometry (higher differential geometry). It studies smooth ‚àû-groupoids and L-‚àû algebroids and their relation via Lie integration and Lie differentiation.
A Lie algebra is the infinitesimal approximation to a Lie group.
Ordinary definition
A Lie algebra is a vector space ùî§\mathfrak{g} equipped with a bilinear skew-symmetric map [‚àí,‚àí]:ùî§‚àßùî§‚Üíùî§[-,-]  : \mathfrak{g} \wedge \mathfrak{g} \to \mathfrak{g} which satisfies the Jacobi identity:
‚àÄx,y,z‚ààùî§:[x,[y,z]]+[z,[x,y]]+[y,[z,x]]=0.
  \forall x,y,z \in \mathfrak{g} : \left[x,\left[y,z\right]\right] + \left[z,\left[x,y\right]\right] + \left[y,\left[z,x\right]\right] = 0
  \,.


A homomorphism of Lie algebras is a linear map œï:ùî§‚Üíùî•\phi : \mathfrak{g} \to \mathfrak{h} such that for all x,y‚ààùî§x,y \in \mathfrak{g} we have
œï([x,y] ùî§)=[œï(x),œï(y)] ùî•.
  \phi([x,y]_{\mathfrak{g}}) = [\phi(x),\phi(y)]_{\mathfrak{h}}
  \,.


This defines the category LieAlg of Lie algebras.
Internal to a general linear category
The notion of Lie algebra may be formulated internal to any linear category. This general definition subsumes variants of Lie algebras such as super Lie algebras.
Consider a commutative unital ring kk, and a (strict for simplicity) symmetric monoidal kk-linear category (ùíû,‚äó,1)(\mathcal{C},\otimes,1) with braiding œÑ\tau.
A Lie algebra object in (ùíû,‚äó,1,œÑ)(\mathcal{C},\otimes,1,\tau) is


an object
L‚ààùíû
  L \in \mathcal{C}



morphism (the Lie bracket)
[‚àí,‚àí]:L‚äóL‚ÜíL
  [-,-] \;\colon\; L \otimes L \to L



such that the following conditions hold:


Jacobi identity:
[‚àí,[‚àí,‚àí]]+[‚àí,[‚àí,‚àí]]‚àò(id L‚äóœÑ L,L)‚àò(œÑ‚äóid L)+[‚àí,[‚àí,‚àí]]‚àò(œÑ L,L‚äóid L)‚àò(id L‚äóœÑ L,L)=0
  \left[-,\left[-,-\right]\right]
    +
  \left[-,\left[-,-\right]\right]
  \circ(id_L\otimes\tau_{L,L})
  \circ(\tau\otimes id_L)
  +
  \left[-,\left[-,-\right]\right]
    \circ 
  (\tau_{L,L}\otimes id_L)\circ (id_L\otimes\tau_{L,L}) = 0



skew-symmetry:
 +[‚àí,‚àí]  +[‚àí,‚àí]‚àòœÑ L,L  =+0
  \begin{aligned}
    & 
    \phantom{+}
    [-,-]
    \\
    &
    +
    [-,-]\circ \tau_{L,L} 
    \\
    & = \phantom{+} 0
  \end{aligned}



Equivalently, Lie algebra objects are the algebras over an operad over a certain quadratic operad, called the Lie operad, which is the Koszul dual of the commutative algebra operad.
Examples of types of Lie algebra objects:
If kk is the ring ‚Ñ§\mathbb{Z} of integers and ùíû=\mathcal{C} =  kkMod = Ab is the category of abelian groups equipped with the tensor product of abelian groups, then a Lie algebra object is called a Lie ring.
If kk is a field and ùíû=\mathcal{C} = Vect is the category of vector spaces over kk equipped with the tensor product of vector spaces then a Lie algebra object is an ordinary_Lie k-algebra.
If kk is a field and ùíû\mathcal{C} = sVect is the category of super vector spaces over kk, then a Lie algebra object is a super Lie algebra.
General abstract perspective
Lie algebras are equivalently groups in ‚Äúinfinitesimal geometry‚Äù.
For instance in synthetic differential geometry then a Lie algebra of a Lie group is just the first-order infinitesimal neighbourhood of the unit element (e.g. Kock 09, section 6).
More generally in geometric homotopy theory, Lie algebras, being 0-truncated L-‚àû algebras are equivalently ‚Äúinfinitesimal ‚àû-group geometric ‚àû-stacks‚Äù (e.g. here-topos#FormalModuliProblems)), also called formal moduli problems (see there for more).

Lie's three theorems




L ‚àûL_\infty-algebras (or strong homotopy Lie algebras) are a higher generalization (a ‚Äúvertical categorification‚Äù) of Lie algebras: in an L ‚àûL_\infty-algebra the Jacobi identity is allowed to hold (only) up to higher coherent homotopy.
An L ‚àûL_\infty-algebra that is concentrated in lowest degree is an ordinary Lie algebra. If it is concentrated in the lowest two degrees is is a Lie 2-algebra, etc.
From another perspective: an L ‚àûL_\infty-algebra is a Lie ‚àû-algebroid with a single object.
L ‚àûL_\infty-algebras are infinitesimal approximations of smooth ‚àû-groups in analogy to how an ordinary Lie algebra is an infinitesimal approximation of a Lie group. Under Lie integration every L ‚àûL_\infty-algebra ùî§\mathfrak{g} ‚Äúexponentiates‚Äù to a smooth ‚àû-group Œ©exp(ùî§)\Omega \exp(\mathfrak{g}).
In terms of algebras over an operad
An L ‚àûL_\infty-algebra is an algebra over an operad in the category of chain complexes over the L-‚àû operad.
In the following we spell out in detail what this means in components.
In terms of higher brackets
We now state the definition of L ‚àûL_\infty-algebras that is most directly related to the traditional definition of ordinary Lie algebras, namely as ‚Ñ§\mathbb{Z}-graded vector space ùî§\mathfrak{g} equipped with nn-ary multilinear and graded-skew symmetric maps [‚àí,‚ãØ,‚àí][-,\cdots,-] ‚Äì the ‚Äúbrackets‚Äù ‚Äì that satisfy a generalization of the Jacobi identity.
To that end, we here choose grading conventions such that the following definition of L ‚àûL_\infty-algebras reduces to that of ordinary Lie algebras when ùî§\mathfrak{g} is concentrated in degree zero. Moreover we take the differential of the underlying chain complex of the L ‚àûL_\infty-algebra to have degree ‚àí1-1 (‚Äúhomological grading‚Äù). Together this means in particular that ùî§\mathfrak{g} is a Lie n-algebra for n‚àà‚Ñïn \in \mathbb{N}, n‚â•1n \geq 1, if it is concentrated in degrees 0 to n‚àí1n-1.
Beware that there are also other conventions possible, and there are other conventions in use, for both these choices, leading to different signs in the following formulas.

Definition
(graded signature of a permuation)
Let VV be a ‚Ñ§\mathbb{Z}-graded vector space, and for n‚àà‚Ñïn \in \mathbb{N} let
v=(v 1,v 2,‚ãØ,v n)
  \mathbf{v} = (v_1, v_2, \cdots, v_n)


be an n-tuple of elements of VV of homogeneous degree |v i|‚àà‚Ñ§\vert v_i \vert  \in \mathbb{Z}, i.e. such that v i‚ààV |v i|v_i \in V_{\vert v_i\vert}.
For œÉ\sigma a permutation of nn elements, write (‚àí1) |œÉ|(-1)^{\vert \sigma \vert} for the signature of the permutation, which is by definition equal to (‚àí1) k(-1)^k if œÉ\sigma is the composite of k‚àà‚Ñïk \in \mathbb{N} permutations that each exchange precisely one pair of neighboring elements.
We say that the v\mathbf{v}-graded signature of œÉ\sigma
œá(œÉ,v 1,‚ãØ,v n)‚àà{‚àí1,+1}
  \chi(\sigma, v_1, \cdots, v_n) \;\in\; \{-1,+1\}


is the product of the signature of the permutation (‚àí1) |œÉ|(-1)^{\vert \sigma \vert} with a factor of (‚àí1) |v i||v j|(-1)^{\vert v_i \vert \vert v_j \vert} for each interchange of neighbours (‚ãØv i,v j,‚ãØ)(\cdots v_i,v_j, \cdots ) to (‚ãØv j,v i,‚ãØ)(\cdots v_j,v_i, \cdots ) involved in the decomposition of the permuation as a sequence of swapping neighbour pairs.

Example
In lowest degrees the generalized Jacobi identity says that


for n=1n = 1: the unary map ‚àÇ‚âîl 1\partial \coloneqq l_1 squares to 0:
‚àÇ(‚àÇ(v 1))=0
  \partial (\partial(v_1)) = 0



for n=2n = 2: the unary map ‚àÇ\partial is a graded derivation of the binary map
‚àí[‚àÇv 1,v 2]‚àí(‚àí1) |v 1||v 2|[‚àÇv 2,v 1]+‚àÇ[v 1,v 2]=0
  - [\partial v_1, v_2] 
  - (-1)^{\vert v_1 \vert \vert v_2 \vert}
  [\partial v_2, v_1]
  +
  \partial [v_1, v_2]
  =
  0


hence
‚àÇ[v 1,v 2]=[‚àÇv 1,v 2]+(‚àí1) |v 1|[v 1,‚àÇv 2].
  \partial [v_1, v_2] =  [\partial v_1, v_2] + (-1)^{\vert v_1 \vert} [v_1, \partial v_2]
  \,.





Example

[[v 1,v 2],v 3]+(‚àí1) |v 1|(|v 2|+|v 3|)[[v 2,v 3],v 1]+(‚àí1) |v 2|(|v 1|+|v 3|)[[v 1,v 3],v 2]=0
  [[v_1,v_2],v_3] 
  +
  (-1)^{\vert v_1 \vert (\vert v_2 \vert + \vert v_3 \vert)}
  [[v_2,v_3],v_1]

this is the graded Jacobi identity. So in this case the L ‚àûL_\infty-algebra is equivalently a dg-Lie algebra.


Example
When l 3l_3 is possibly non-vanishing, then on elements x ix_i on which ‚àÇ=l 1\partial = l_1 vanishes then the generalized Jacobi identity for n=3n = 3 gives
[[v 1,v 2],v 3]+(‚àí1) |v 1|(|v 2|+|v 3|)[[v 2,v 3],v 1]+(‚àí1) |v 2|(|v 1|+|v 3|)[[v 1,v 3],v 2]=‚àí‚àÇ[v 1,v 2,v 3].
  [[v_1,v_2],v_3]

  [[v_1,v_3],v_2]
  =
  - \partial [v_1, v_2, v_3]
  \,.


This shows that the Jacobi identity holds up to an ‚Äúexact‚Äù term, hence up to homotopy.

In terms of semifree differential coalgebra
In (Lada-Stasheff 92) it was pointed out that the higher brackets of an L ‚àûL_\infty-algebra (def. ) induce on the graded-co-commutative cofree coalgebra ‚à® ‚Ä¢ùî§\vee^\bullet \mathfrak{g} over the underlying graded vector space ùî§\mathfrak{g} the structure of a differential graded coalgebra, with differential D=[‚àí]+[‚àí,‚àí]+[‚àí,‚àí,‚àí]+‚ãØD = [-] + [-,-] + [-,-,-] + \cdots the sum of the higher brackets, extended as graded coderivations. The higher Jacobi identity is equivalently the condition that D 2=0D^2 = 0. In (Lada-Markl 94) it was observed that conversely, such ‚Äúsemifree‚Äù differential graded coalgebras are an equivalent incarnation of L ‚àûL_\infty-algebras.
(If one uses unital dg-co-algebras then the L ‚àûL_\infty-algbras encoded with way are generally curved L-infinity algebras. To restrict to the non-curved one one either considers co-augmented unital dg-co-algebras or non-unital coalgebras.)
Notice that this immediately imples that if ùî§\mathfrak{g} is degreewise finite dimensional, then passing to dual vector spaces turns semifree differential graded coalgebra into semifree differential graded algebras, which hence are opposite-equivalent to L ‚àûL_\infty-algebras of finite type. For ùî§\mathfrak{g} an ordinary finite dimensional Lie algebra, then this dg-algebras is its Chevalley-Eilenberg algebra, hence we may generally speak of Chevalley-Eilenberg algebras of L ‚àûL_\infty-algebras of finite type (and also more generally, if one invokes pro-objects, see at model structure for L-infinity algebras ‚Äì Use of pro-dg-algebras ).
In term of the operadic definition of L ‚àûL_\infty-algebras above this equivalence is an incarnation of the Koszul duality between the Lie operad and the commutative operad.
We now spell out this dg-coalgebraic incarnation of L ‚àûL_\infty-algebras.
A (connected) L ‚àûL_\infty-algebra is


an ‚Ñï +\mathbb{N}_+-graded vector space ùî§\mathfrak{g};


equipped with a differential D:‚à® ‚Ä¢ùî§‚Üí‚à® ‚Ä¢ùî§D : \vee^\bullet \mathfrak{g} \to \vee^\bullet \mathfrak{g} of degree ‚àí1-1 on the free graded co-commutative coalgebra over ùî§\mathfrak{g} that squares to 0


D 2=0.
  D^2 = 0
  \,.


Here the free graded co-commutative co-algebra ‚à® ‚Ä¢ùî§\vee^\bullet \mathfrak{g} is, as a vector space, the same as the graded Grassmann algebra ‚àß ‚Ä¢ùî§\wedge^\bullet \mathfrak{g} whose elements we write as
3t 1‚à®t 2+t 3+t 3‚à®t 4‚à®t 5
  3 t_1 \vee t_2 + t_3 + t_3 \vee t_4 \vee t_5


etc (where the ‚à®\vee is just a funny way to write the wedge ‚àß\wedge, in order to remind us that:‚Ä¶)
but thought of as equipped with the standard coproduct
Œî(v 1‚à®v 2‚ãØ‚à®v n)‚àù‚àë i¬±(v 1‚à®‚ãØ‚à®v i)‚äó(v i+1‚à®‚ãØ‚à®v n)
  \Delta (v_1 \vee v_2 \cdots \vee v_n)
  \propto \sum_i \pm (v_1 \vee \cdots \vee v_i) \otimes (v_{i+1} \vee \cdots \vee v_n)



(work out or see the references for the signs and prefacors).

Since this is a free graded co-commutative coalgebra, one can see that any differential
D:‚à® ‚Ä¢ùî§‚Üí‚à® ‚Ä¢ùî§
  D : \vee^\bullet \mathfrak{g} \to \vee^\bullet \mathfrak{g}


on it is fixed by its value ‚Äúon cogenerators‚Äù (a statement that is maybe unfamiliar, but simply the straightforward dual of the more familar statement to which we come below, that differentials on free graded algebras are fixed by their action on generators) which means that we can decompose DD as
D=D 1+D 2+D 3+‚ãØ,
  D = D_1 +  D_2 + D_3 + \cdots
  \,,


where each D iD_i acts as l il_i when evaluated on a homogeneous element of the form t 1‚à®‚ãØ‚à®t nt_1 \vee \cdots \vee t_n and is then uniquely extended to all of ‚à® ‚Ä¢ùî§\vee^\bullet \mathfrak{g} by extending it as a coderivation on a coalgebra.
For instance D 2D_2 acts on homogeneous elements of word lenght 3 as
D 2(t 1‚à®t 2‚à®t 3)=D 2(t 1,t 2)‚à®t 3¬±permutations.
  D_2(t_1 \vee t_2 \vee t_3) = 
  D_2(t_1, t_2)\vee t_3 \pm permutations
  \,.



exercise for the reader: spell this all out more in detail with all the signs and everyrthing. Possibly by looking it up in the references given below.

Using this, one checks that the simple condition that DD squares to 0 is precisely equivalent to the infinite tower of generalized Jacobi identities:
(D 2=0)‚áî(‚àÄn:‚àë i+j=n‚àë shufflesœÉ¬±l i(l j(v œÉ(1),‚ãØ,v œÉ(j)),v œÉ(j+1),‚ãØ,v œÉ(n))=0).
  (D^2 = 0)
  \Leftrightarrow
  \left(
    \forall n : 
  \sum_{i+j = n} \sum_{shuffles \sigma}
  \pm l_i (l_j (v_{\sigma(1)}, \cdots, v_{\sigma(j)} )
   , v_{\sigma(j+1)} , \cdots , v_{\sigma(n)} ) = 0
  \right)
  \,.


So in conclusion we have:

An L ‚àûL_\infty-algebra is a dg-coalgebra whose underlying coalgebra is cofree and concentrated in negative degree.

In terms of semifree differential algebra
The reformulation of an L ‚àûL_\infty-algebra as simply a semi-co-free graded-co-commutative coalgebra (‚à® ‚Ä¢ùî§,D)(\vee^\bullet \mathfrak{g}, D) is a useful repackaging of the original definition, but the coalgebraic aspect tends to be not only unfamiliar, but also a bit inconvenient. At least when the graded vector space ùî§\mathfrak{g} is degreewise finite dimensional, we may simply pass to its degreewise dual graded vector space ùî§ *\mathfrak{g}^*.
(Fully generally the following works when using not just dg-algebras but pro-objects in dg-algebras, see at model structure for L-infinity algebras ‚Äì Use of pro-dg-algebras).
Its Grassmann algebra ‚àß ‚Ä¢ùî§ *\wedge^\bullet \mathfrak{g}^* is then naturally equipped with an ordinary differential d=D *d = D^* which acts on œâ‚àà‚àß ‚Ä¢ùî§ *\omega \in \wedge^\bullet \mathfrak{g}^* as
(dœâ)(t 1‚à®‚ãØ‚à®t n)=¬±œâ(D(t 1‚à®‚ãØ‚à®t n)).
  (d \omega) (t_1 \vee \cdots \vee t_n) =
  \pm \omega(D(t_1 \vee \cdots \vee t_n))
  \,.


When the grading-dust has settled one finds that with
‚àß ‚Ä¢ùî§ *=k‚äïùî§ 1 *‚äï(ùî§ 1 *‚àßùî§ 1 *‚äïùî§ 2 *)‚äï‚ãØ
  \wedge^\bullet \mathfrak{g}^* =
  k \oplus \mathfrak{g}^*_1 \oplus (\mathfrak{g}^*_1 \wedge \mathfrak{g}^*_1 \oplus \mathfrak{g}^*_2) \oplus \cdots


with the ground field in degree 0, the degree 1-elements of ùî§ *\mathfrak{g}^* in degree 1, etc, that dd is of degree +1 and of course squares to 0
d 2=0.
  d^2 = 0
  \,.


This means that we have a semifree dga
CE(ùî§):=(‚àß ‚Ä¢ùî§ *,d).
  CE(\mathfrak{g}) := (\wedge^\bullet \mathfrak{g}^*, d)
  \,.


In the case that ùî§\mathfrak{g} happens to be an ordinary Lie algebra, this is the ordinary Chevalley-Eilenberg algebra of this Lie algebra. Hence we should generally call CE(ùî§)CE(\mathfrak{g}) the Chevalley-Eilenberg algebra of the L ‚àûL_\infty-algebra ùî§\mathfrak{g}.
One observes that this construction is bijective: every (degreewise finite dimensional) cochain semifree dga generated in positive degree comes from a (degreewise finite dimensional) L ‚àûL_\infty-algebra this way.
This means that we may just as well define a (degreewise finite dimensional) L ‚àûL_\infty-algebra as an object in the opposite category of (degreewise finite dimensional) commutative dg-algebras that are semifree dgas and generated in positive degree.
(In general this corresponds to curved L-infinity algebra. The flat L ‚àûL_\infty-algebras ùî§\mathfrak{g} dually correspond to the dg-algebras which are augmented over ‚Ñù\mathbb{R}, i.e for which the canonical projection CE(ùî§)‚ü∂‚ÑùCE(\mathfrak{g}) \longrightarrow \mathbb{R} is a homomorphism of dg-algebras.)
And this turns out to be one of the most useful perspectives on L ‚àûL_\infty-algebras.
In particular, if we simply drop the condition that the dg-algebra be generated in positive degree and allow it to be generated in non-negative degree over the algebra in degree 0, then we have the notion of the (Chevalley-Eilenberg algebra of) an L-infinity-algebroid.
Details
We discuss in explit detail the computation that shows that an L ‚àûL_\infty-algebra structure on ùî§\mathfrak{g} is equivalently a dg-algebra-structure on ‚àß ‚Ä¢ùî§ *\wedge^\bullet \mathfrak{g}^*.
Let ùî§\mathfrak{g} be a degreewise finite-dimensional ‚Ñï +\mathbb{N}_+graded vector space equipped with multilinear graded-symmetric maps
[‚àí,‚ãØ,‚àí] k:Sym kùî§‚Üíùî§
  [-,\cdots,-]_k : Sym^k \mathfrak{g} \to \mathfrak{g}


of degree -1, for each k‚àà‚Ñï +k \in \mathbb{N}_+.
Let {t a}\{t_a\} be a basis of ùî§\mathfrak{g} and {t a}\{t^a\} a dual basis of the degreewise dual ùî§ *\mathfrak{g}^*. Equip the Grassmann algebra Sym ‚Ä¢ùî§ *Sym^\bullet \mathfrak{g}^* with a derivation
d:Sym ‚Ä¢ùî§ *‚ÜíSym ‚Ä¢ùî§ *
  d : Sym^\bullet \mathfrak{g}^* \to Sym^\bullet \mathfrak{g}^*


defined on generators by
d:t a‚Ü¶‚àí‚àë k=1 ‚àû1k![t a 1,‚ãØ,t a k] k at a 1‚àß‚ãØ‚àßt a k.
  d : t^a 
    \mapsto 
    -
   \sum_{k = 1}^\infty 
    \frac{1}{k!}
   [t_{a_1}, \cdots, t_{a_k}]^a_k
   \,
   t^{a_1} \wedge \cdots \wedge t^{a_k}
  \,.


Here we take t at^a to be of the same degree as t at_a. Therefore this derivation has degree +1.
We compute the square d 2=d‚àòdd^2 = d \circ d:
ddt a =d(‚àí1)‚àë k=1 ‚àû1k![t a 1,‚ãØ,t a k] k at a 1‚àß‚ãØ‚àßt a k  =‚àë k,l=1 ‚àû1(k‚àí1)!l![[t b 1,‚ãØ,t b l],t a 2,‚ãØ,t a k] at b 1‚àß‚ãØ‚àßt b l‚àßt a 2‚àß‚ãØ‚àßt a k.
  \begin{aligned}
    d d t^a 
      &= 
    d (-1)\sum_{k = 1}^\infty 
    \frac{1}{k!}
    [t_{a_1}, \cdots, t_{a_k}]^a_k
   \,
   t^{a_1} \wedge \cdots \wedge t^{a_k}
    \\
    & = 
    \sum_{k,l = 1}^\infty
    \frac{1}{(k-1)! l!}
    [[t_{b_1}, \cdots, t_{b_l}], t_{a_2}, \cdots, t_{a_k}]^a
    \,
    t^{b_1} \wedge \cdots \wedge t^{b_l}  
    \wedge  
    t^{a_2} \wedge \cdots \wedge t^{a_{k}}
  \end{aligned}
  \,.


Here the wedge product on the right projects the nested bracket onto its graded-symmetric components. This is produced by summing over all permutations œÉ‚ààŒ£ k+l‚àí1\sigma \in \Sigma_{k+l-1} weighted by the Koszul-signature of the permutation:
‚ãØ=‚àë k,l=1 ‚àû1(k+l‚àí1)!‚àë œÉ‚ààŒ£ k+l‚àí1(‚àí1) sgn(œÉ)1(k‚àí1)!l![[t b 1,‚ãØ,t b l],t a 2,‚ãØ,t a k] at b 1‚àß‚ãØ‚àßt b l‚àßt a 2‚àß‚ãØ‚àßt a k.
  \cdots = 
    \sum_{k,l = 1}^\infty
    \frac{1}{(k+l-1)!}
    \sum_{\sigma \in \Sigma_{k+l-1}}
    (-1)^{sgn(\sigma)}
    \frac{1}{(k-1)! l!}
    [[t_{b_1}, \cdots, t_{b_l}], t_{a_2}, \cdots, t_{a_k}]^a
    \,
    t^{b_1} \wedge \cdots \wedge t^{b_l}  
    \wedge  
    t^{a_2} \wedge \cdots \wedge t^{a_{k}}
  \,.


The sum over all permutations decomposes into a sum over the (l,k‚àí1)(l,k-1)-unshuffles and a sum over permutations that act inside the first ll and the last (k‚àí1)(k-1) indices. By the graded-symmetry of the bracket, the latter do not change the value of the nested bracket. Since there are (k‚àí1)!l!(k-1)! l! many of them, we get
‚ãØ=‚àë k,l=1 ‚àû1(k+l‚àí1)!‚àë œÉ‚ààUnsh(l,k‚àí1)(‚àí1) sgn(œÉ)[[t a 1,‚ãØ,t a l],t a l+1,‚ãØ,t a k+l‚àí1]t a 1‚àß‚ãØ‚àßt a k+l‚àí1.
  \cdots 
    =
    \sum_{k,l = 1}^\infty
    \frac{1}{(k+l-1)!}
    \sum_{\sigma \in Unsh(l,k-1)}
    (-1)^{sgn(\sigma)}
    \left[\left[t_{a_1}, \cdots, t_{a_l}\right], t_{a_{l+1}}, \cdots, t_{a_{k+l-1}}\right]
    \,
    t^{a_1} \wedge \cdots \wedge t^{a_{k+l-1}}
  \,.


Therefore the condition d 2=0d^2 = 0 is equivalent to the condition
‚àë k+l=n‚àí1‚àë œÉ‚ààUnsh(l,k‚àí1)(‚àí1) sgn(œÉ)[[t a 1,‚ãØ,t a l],t a l+1,‚ãØ,t a k+l‚àí1]=0
    \sum_{k+l = n-1}
    \sum_{\sigma \in Unsh(l,k-1)}
    (-1)^{sgn(\sigma)}
    \left[\left[t_{a_1}, \cdots, t_{a_l}\right], t_{a_{l+1}}, \cdots, t_{a_{k+l-1}}\right]
  = 0


for all n‚àà‚Ñïn \in \mathbb{N} and all {t a i‚ààùî§}\{t_{a_i} \in \mathfrak{g}\}. This is equation (1) which says that {ùî§,{[‚àí,‚Ä¶,‚àí] k}}\{\mathfrak{g}, \{[-,\dots,-]_k\}\} is an L ‚àûL_\infty-algebra.
In terms of algebras over an operad
L ‚àûL_\infty-algebras are precisely the algebras over an operad of the cofibrant resolution of the Lie operad.
Ind-Conilpotency

Remark
(Pridham 10, remark 3.15, remark 3.13)
For ùî§\mathfrak{g} an L ‚àûL_\infty-algebra, then its CE chain dgc-coalgebra CE ‚Ä¢(ùî§)CE_\bullet(\mathfrak{g}) (above) is ind-conilpotent.
This means that CE ‚Ä¢(ùî§)CE_\bullet(\mathfrak{g}) is a filtered colimit of sub-dg-coalgebras which are conilpotent, in that for each of them there is n‚àà‚Ñïn \in \mathbb{N} such that their nn-fold coproduct vanishes. As such these are like ‚Äúco-local Artin algebras‚Äù.
Moreover, since every dg-coalgebra is the union of its finite-dimensonal subalgebras (see at dg-coalgebra the section As filtered colimits of finite-dimensional pieces), this means that CE ‚Ä¢(ùî§)CE_\bullet(\mathfrak{g}) is a filtered colimit of finite dimensional conilpotent coalgebras.
This implies that the dual Chevalley-Eilenberg cochain algebra CE ‚Ä¢(ùî§)CE^\bullet(\mathfrak{g}) is a filtered limit of finite-dimensional nilpotent dgc-algebras (actual local Artin algebras).

Model category structure
See model structure for L-‚àû algebras.
Relation to dg-Lie algebras
Every dg-Lie algebra is in an evident way an L ‚àûL_\infty-algebra. Dg-Lie algebras are precisely those L ‚àûL_\infty-algebras for which all nn-ary brackets for n>2n \gt 2 are trivial. These may be thought of as the strict L ‚àûL_\infty-algebras: those for which the Jacobi identity holds on the nose and all its possible higher coherences are trivial.

Theorem
Let kk be a field of characteristic 0 and write L ‚àûAlg kL_\infty Alg_k for the category of L‚àûL\infty-algebras over kk.
Then every object of L ‚àûAlg kL_\infty Alg_k is quasi-isomorphic to a dg-Lie algebra.
Moreover, one can find a functorial replacement: there is a functor
W:L ‚àûAlg k‚ÜíL ‚àûAlg k
  W : L_\infty Alg_k \to L_\infty Alg_k


such that for each ùî§‚ààL ‚àûAlg k\mathfrak{g} \in L_\infty Alg_k


W(ùî®)W(\mathfrak{k}) is a dg-Lie algebra;


there is a quasi-isomorphism
ùî§‚Üí‚âÉW(ùî§).
  \mathfrak{g} \stackrel{\simeq}{\to}
  W(\mathfrak{g})
  \,.




This appears for instance as (Kriz & May 1995, Cor. 1.6).
For more see at relation between L-‚àû algebras and dg-Lie algebras.
Relation to ‚àû\infty-Lie groupoids
In generalization to how a Lie algebra integrates to a Lie group, L ‚àûL_\infty-algebras integrate to ‚àû-Lie groups.
See
Lie integration
and
Lie integrated ‚àû-Lie groupoids.
L ‚àûL_\infty-algebras (or strong homotopy Lie algebras) are a higher generalization (a ‚Äúvertical categorification‚Äù) of Lie algebras: in an L ‚àûL_\infty-algebra the Jacobi identity is allowed to hold (only) up to higher coherent homotopy.
An L ‚àûL_\infty-algebra that is concentrated in lowest degree is an ordinary Lie algebra. If it is concentrated in the lowest two degrees is is a Lie 2-algebra, etc.
From another perspective: an L ‚àûL_\infty-algebra is a Lie ‚àû-algebroid with a single object.
L ‚àûL_\infty-algebras are infinitesimal approximations of smooth ‚àû-groups in analogy to how an ordinary Lie algebra is an infinitesimal approximation of a Lie group. Under Lie integration every L ‚àûL_\infty-algebra ùî§\mathfrak{g} ‚Äúexponentiates‚Äù to a smooth ‚àû-group Œ©exp(ùî§)\Omega \exp(\mathfrak{g}).
In terms of algebras over an operad
An L ‚àûL_\infty-algebra is an algebra over an operad in the category of chain complexes over the L-‚àû operad.
In the following we spell out in detail what this means in components.
In terms of higher brackets
We now state the definition of L ‚àûL_\infty-algebras that is most directly related to the traditional definition of ordinary Lie algebras, namely as ‚Ñ§\mathbb{Z}-graded vector space ùî§\mathfrak{g} equipped with nn-ary multilinear and graded-skew symmetric maps [‚àí,‚ãØ,‚àí][-,\cdots,-] ‚Äì the ‚Äúbrackets‚Äù ‚Äì that satisfy a generalization of the Jacobi identity.
To that end, we here choose grading conventions such that the following definition of L ‚àûL_\infty-algebras reduces to that of ordinary Lie algebras when ùî§\mathfrak{g} is concentrated in degree zero. Moreover we take the differential of the underlying chain complex of the L ‚àûL_\infty-algebra to have degree ‚àí1-1 (‚Äúhomological grading‚Äù). Together this means in particular that ùî§\mathfrak{g} is a Lie n-algebra for n‚àà‚Ñïn \in \mathbb{N}, n‚â•1n \geq 1, if it is concentrated in degrees 0 to n‚àí1n-1.
Beware that there are also other conventions possible, and there are other conventions in use, for both these choices, leading to different signs in the following formulas.

Definition
(graded signature of a permuation)
Let VV be a ‚Ñ§\mathbb{Z}-graded vector space, and for n‚àà‚Ñïn \in \mathbb{N} let
v=(v 1,v 2,‚ãØ,v n)
  \mathbf{v} = (v_1, v_2, \cdots, v_n)


be an n-tuple of elements of VV of homogeneous degree |v i|‚àà‚Ñ§\vert v_i \vert  \in \mathbb{Z}, i.e. such that v i‚ààV |v i|v_i \in V_{\vert v_i\vert}.
For œÉ\sigma a permutation of nn elements, write (‚àí1) |œÉ|(-1)^{\vert \sigma \vert} for the signature of the permutation, which is by definition equal to (‚àí1) k(-1)^k if œÉ\sigma is the composite of k‚àà‚Ñïk \in \mathbb{N} permutations that each exchange precisely one pair of neighboring elements.
We say that the v\mathbf{v}-graded signature of œÉ\sigma
œá(œÉ,v 1,‚ãØ,v n)‚àà{‚àí1,+1}
  \chi(\sigma, v_1, \cdots, v_n) \;\in\; \{-1,+1\}


is the product of the signature of the permutation (‚àí1) |œÉ|(-1)^{\vert \sigma \vert} with a factor of (‚àí1) |v i||v j|(-1)^{\vert v_i \vert \vert v_j \vert} for each interchange of neighbours (‚ãØv i,v j,‚ãØ)(\cdots v_i,v_j, \cdots ) to (‚ãØv j,v i,‚ãØ)(\cdots v_j,v_i, \cdots ) involved in the decomposition of the permuation as a sequence of swapping neighbour pairs.


Definition
An L ‚àûL_\infty-algebra is


a ‚Ñ§\mathbb{Z}-graded vector space ùî§\mathfrak{g};


for each n‚àà‚Ñïn \in \mathbb{N}, n‚â•1n \geq 1 a multilinear map, called the nn-ary bracket, of the form
l n(‚ãØ)‚âî[‚àí,‚àí,‚ãØ,‚àí] n:ùî§‚äó‚ãØ‚äóùî§‚èüncopies‚ü∂ùî§
  l_n(\cdots) 
    \;\coloneqq\; 
  [-,-, \cdots, -]_n

    \underset{n \; \text{copies}}{\underbrace{\mathfrak{g} \otimes \cdots \otimes \mathfrak{g}}}
    \longrightarrow
    \mathfrak{g}

(graded skew symmetry) each l nl_n is graded antisymmetric, in that for every permutation œÉ\sigma of nn elements and for every n-tuple (v 1,‚ãØ,v n)(v_1, \cdots, v_n) of homogeneously graded elements v i‚ààùî§ |v i|v_i \in \mathfrak{g}_{\vert v_i \vert} then
l n(v œÉ(1),v œÉ(2),‚ãØ,v œÉ(n))=œá(œÉ,v 1,‚ãØ,v n)‚ãÖl n(v 1,v 2,‚ãØv n)
  l_n(v_{\sigma(1)}, v_{\sigma(2)},\cdots ,v_{\sigma(n)}) 
  = 
  \chi(\sigma,v_1,\cdots, v_n) \cdot l_n(v_1, v_2, \cdots v_n)


where œá(œÉ,v 1,‚ãØ,v n)\chi(\sigma,v_1,\cdots, v_n) is the (v 1,‚ãØ,v n)(v_1,\cdots,v_n)-graded signature of the permuation œÉ\sigma, according to def. ;


(strong homotopy Jacobi identity) for all n‚àà‚Ñïn \in \mathbb{N}, and for all 


n

(1)‚àë i,j‚àà‚Ñïi+j=n+1‚àë œÉ‚ààUnShuff(i,j‚àí1)œá(œÉ,v 1,‚ãØ,v n)(‚àí1) i(j‚àí1)l j(l i(v œÉ(1),‚ãØ,v œÉ(i)),v œÉ(i+1),‚ãØ,v œÉ(n))=0,

     l_i \left( v_{\sigma(1)}, \cdots, v_{\sigma(i)} \right),
     v_{\sigma(i+1)} , \cdots , v_{\sigma(n)}
   \right)
  = 0
  \,,


where the inner sum runs over all (i,j‚àí1)(i,j-1)-unshuffles œÉ\sigma and where œá\chi is the graded signature sign from def. .




Example
In lowest degrees the generalized Jacobi identity says that


for n=1n = 1: the unary map ‚àÇ‚âîl 1\partial \coloneqq l_1 squares to 0:
‚àÇ(‚àÇ(v 1))=0
  \partial (\partial(v_1)) = 0



for n=2n = 2: the unary map ‚àÇ\partial is a graded derivation of the binary map
‚àí[‚àÇv 1,v 2]‚àí(‚àí1) |v 1||v 2|[‚àÇv 2,v 1]+‚àÇ[v 1,v 2]=0
  - [\partial v_1, v_2] 
  - (-1)^{\vert v_1 \vert \vert v_2 \vert}
  [\partial v_2, v_1]
  +
  \partial [v_1, v_2]
  =
  0


hence
‚àÇ[v 1,v 2]=[‚àÇv 1,v 2]+(‚àí1) |v 1|[v 1,‚àÇv 2].
  \partial [v_1, v_2] =  [\partial v_1, v_2] + (-1)^{\vert v_1 \vert} [v_1, \partial v_2]
  \,.





Example
When all higher brackets vanish, l k>2=0l_{k \gt 2}= 0 then for n=3n = 3:
[[v 1,v 2],v 3]+(‚àí1) |v 1|(|v 2|+|v 3|)[[v 2,v 3],v 1]+(‚àí1) |v 2|(|v 1|+|v 3|)[[v 1,v 3],v 2]=0
  [[v_1,v_2],v_3] 
  +
  (-1)^{\vert v_1 \vert (\vert v_2 \vert + \vert v_3 \vert)}
  [[v_2,v_3],v_1]
  +
  (-1)^{\vert v_2 \vert (\vert v_1 \vert + \vert v_3 \vert)}
  [[v_1,v_3],v_2]
  =
  0


this is the graded Jacobi identity. So in this case the L ‚àûL_\infty-algebra is equivalently a dg-Lie algebra.


Example
When l 3l_3 is possibly non-vanishing, then on elements x ix_i on which ‚àÇ=l 1\partial = l_1 vanishes then the generalized Jacobi identity for n=3n = 3 gives
[[v 1,v 2],v 3]+(‚àí1) |v 1|(|v 2|+|v 3|)[[v 2,v 3],v 1]+(‚àí1) |v 2|(|v 1|+|v 3|)[[v 1,v 3],v 2]=‚àí‚àÇ[v 1,v 2,v 3].
  [[v_1,v_2],v_3] 
  +
  (-1)^{\vert v_1 \vert (\vert v_2 \vert + \vert v_3 \vert)}
  [[v_2,v_3],v_1]
  +
  (-1)^{\vert v_2 \vert (\vert v_1 \vert + \vert v_3 \vert)}
  [[v_1,v_3],v_2]
  =
  - \partial [v_1, v_2, v_3]
  \,.


This shows that the Jacobi identity holds up to an ‚Äúexact‚Äù term, hence up to homotopy.

In terms of semifree differential coalgebra
In (Lada-Stasheff 92) it was pointed out that the higher brackets of an L ‚àûL_\infty-algebra (def. ) induce on the graded-co-commutative cofree coalgebra ‚à® ‚Ä¢ùî§\vee^\bullet \mathfrak{g} over the underlying graded vector space ùî§\mathfrak{g} the structure of a differential graded coalgebra, with differential D=[‚àí]+[‚àí,‚àí]+[‚àí,‚àí,‚àí]+‚ãØD = [-] + [-,-] + [-,-,-] + \cdots the sum of the higher brackets, extended as graded coderivations. The higher Jacobi identity is equivalently the condition that D 2=0D^2 = 0. In (Lada-Markl 94) it was observed that conversely, such ‚Äúsemifree‚Äù differential graded coalgebras are an equivalent incarnation of L ‚àûL_\infty-algebras.
(If one uses unital dg-co-algebras then the L ‚àûL_\infty-algbras encoded with way are generally curved L-infinity algebras. To restrict to the non-curved one one either considers co-augmented unital dg-co-algebras or non-unital coalgebras.)
Notice that this immediately imples that if ùî§\mathfrak{g} is degreewise finite dimensional, then passing to dual vector spaces turns semifree differential graded coalgebra into semifree differential graded algebras, which hence are opposite-equivalent to L ‚àûL_\infty-algebras of finite type. For ùî§\mathfrak{g} an ordinary finite dimensional Lie algebra, then this dg-algebras is its Chevalley-Eilenberg algebra, hence we may generally speak of Chevalley-Eilenberg algebras of L ‚àûL_\infty-algebras of finite type (and also more generally, if one invokes pro-objects, see at model structure for L-infinity algebras ‚Äì Use of pro-dg-algebras ).
In term of the operadic definition of L ‚àûL_\infty-algebras above this equivalence is an incarnation of the Koszul duality between the Lie operad and the commutative operad.
We now spell out this dg-coalgebraic incarnation of L ‚àûL_\infty-algebras.
A (connected) L ‚àûL_\infty-algebra is


an ‚Ñï +\mathbb{N}_+-graded vector space ùî§\mathfrak{g};


equipped with a differential D:‚à® ‚Ä¢ùî§‚Üí‚à® ‚Ä¢ùî§D : \vee^\bullet \mathfrak{g} \to \vee^\bullet \mathfrak{g} of degree ‚àí1-1 on the free graded co-commutative coalgebra over ùî§\mathfrak{g} that squares to 0


D 2=0.
  D^2 = 0
  \,.


Here the free graded co-commutative co-algebra ‚à® ‚Ä¢ùî§\vee^\bullet \mathfrak{g} is, as a vector space, the same as the graded Grassmann algebra ‚àß ‚Ä¢ùî§\wedge^\bullet \mathfrak{g} whose elements we write as
3t 1‚à®t 2+t 3+t 3‚à®t 4‚à®t 5
  3 t_1 \vee t_2 + t_3 + t_3 \vee t_4 \vee t_5


etc (where the ‚à®\vee is just a funny way to write the wedge ‚àß\wedge, in order to remind us that:‚Ä¶)
but thought of as equipped with the standard coproduct
Œî(v 1‚à®v 2‚ãØ‚à®v n)‚àù‚àë i¬±(v 1‚à®‚ãØ‚à®v i)‚äó(v i+1‚à®‚ãØ‚à®v n)
  \Delta (v_1 \vee v_2 \cdots \vee v_n)
  \propto \sum_i \pm (v_1 \vee \cdots \vee v_i) \otimes (v_{i+1} \vee \cdots \vee v_n)



(work out or see the references for the signs and prefacors).

Since this is a free graded co-commutative coalgebra, one can see that any differential

  D : \vee^\bullet \mathfrak{g} \to \vee^\bullet \mathfrak{g}

  D = D_1 +  D_2 + D_3 + \cdots
  \,,


where each D iD_i acts as l il_i when evaluated on a homogeneous element of the form t 1‚à®‚ãØ‚à®t nt_1 \vee \cdots \vee t_n and is then uniquely extended to all of ‚à® ‚Ä¢ùî§\vee^\bullet \mathfrak{g} by extending it as a coderivation on a coalgebra.

  D_2(t_1 \vee t_2 \vee t_3) = 
  D_2(t_1, t_2)\vee t_3 \pm permutations
  \,.

Using this, one checks that the simple condition that DD squares to 0 is precisely equivalent to the infinite tower of generalized Jacobi identities:
(D 2=0)‚áî(‚àÄn:‚àë i+j=n‚àë shufflesœÉ¬±l i(l j(v œÉ(1),‚ãØ,v œÉ(j)),v œÉ(j+1),‚ãØ,v œÉ(n))=0).
  (D^2 = 0)
  \Leftrightarrow
  \left(
    \forall n : 
  \sum_{i+j = n} \sum_{shuffles \sigma}
  \pm l_i (l_j (v_{\sigma(1)}, \cdots, v_{\sigma(j)} )

  \right)
  \,.


So in conclusion we have:

An L ‚àûL_\infty-algebra is a dg-coalgebra whose underlying coalgebra is cofree and concentrated in negative degree.

In terms of semifree differential algebra
The reformulation of an L ‚àûL_\infty-algebra as simply a semi-co-free graded-co-commutative coalgebra (‚à® ‚Ä¢ùî§,D)(\vee^\bullet \mathfrak{g}, D) is a useful repackaging of the original definition, but the coalgebraic aspect tends to be not only unfamiliar, but also a bit inconvenient. At least when the graded vector space ùî§\mathfrak{g} is degreewise finite dimensional, we may simply pass to its degreewise dual graded vector space ùî§ *\mathfrak{g}^*.
(Fully generally the following works when using not just dg-algebras but pro-objects in dg-algebras, see at model structure for L-infinity algebras ‚Äì Use of pro-dg-algebras).
Its Grassmann algebra ‚àß ‚Ä¢ùî§ *\wedge^\bullet \mathfrak{g}^* is then naturally equipped with an ordinary differential d=D *d = D^* which acts on œâ‚àà‚àß ‚Ä¢ùî§ *\omega \in \wedge^\bullet \mathfrak{g}^* as
(dœâ)(t 1‚à®‚ãØ‚à®t n)=¬±œâ(D(t 1‚à®‚ãØ‚à®t n)).
  (d \omega) (t_1 \vee \cdots \vee t_n) =
  \pm \omega(D(t_1 \vee \cdots \vee t_n))
  \,.


When the grading-dust has settled one finds that with
‚àß ‚Ä¢ùî§ *=k‚äïùî§ 1 *‚äï(ùî§ 1 *‚àßùî§ 1 *‚äïùî§ 2 *)‚äï‚ãØ
  \wedge^\bullet \mathfrak{g}^* =
  k \oplus \mathfrak{g}^*_1 \oplus (\mathfrak{g}^*_1 \wedge \mathfrak{g}^*_1 \oplus \mathfrak{g}^*_2) \oplus \cdots


with the ground field in degree 0, the degree 1-elements of ùî§ *\mathfrak{g}^* in degree 1, etc, that dd is of degree +1 and of course squares to 0
d 2=0.
  d^2 = 0
  \,.


This means that we have a semifree dga
CE(ùî§):=(‚àß ‚Ä¢ùî§ *,d).
  CE(\mathfrak{g}) := (\wedge^\bullet \mathfrak{g}^*, d)
  \,.


In the case that ùî§\mathfrak{g} happens to be an ordinary Lie algebra, this is the ordinary Chevalley-Eilenberg algebra of this Lie algebra. Hence we should generally call CE(ùî§)CE(\mathfrak{g}) the Chevalley-Eilenberg algebra of the L ‚àûL_\infty-algebra ùî§\mathfrak{g}.
One observes that this construction is bijective: every (degreewise finite dimensional) cochain semifree dga generated in positive degree comes from a (degreewise finite dimensional) L ‚àûL_\infty-algebra this way.
This means that we may just as well define a (degreewise finite dimensional) L ‚àûL_\infty-algebra as an object in the opposite category of (degreewise finite dimensional) commutative dg-algebras that are semifree dgas and generated in positive degree.
(In general this corresponds to curved L-infinity algebra. The flat L ‚àûL_\infty-algebras ùî§\mathfrak{g} dually correspond to the dg-algebras which are augmented over ‚Ñù\mathbb{R}, i.e for which the canonical projection CE(ùî§)‚ü∂‚ÑùCE(\mathfrak{g}) \longrightarrow \mathbb{R} is a homomorphism of dg-algebras.)
And this turns out to be one of the most useful perspectives on L ‚àûL_\infty-algebras.
In particular, if we simply drop the condition that the dg-algebra be generated in positive degree and allow it to be generated in non-negative degree over the algebra in degree 0, then we have the notion of the (Chevalley-Eilenberg algebra of) an L-infinity-algebroid.
Details
We discuss in explit detail the computation that shows that an L ‚àûL_\infty-algebra structure on ùî§\mathfrak{g} is equivalently a dg-algebra-structure on ‚àß ‚Ä¢ùî§ *\wedge^\bullet \mathfrak{g}^*.
Let ùî§\mathfrak{g} be a degreewise finite-dimensional ‚Ñï +\mathbb{N}_+graded vector space equipped with multilinear graded-symmetric maps
[‚àí,‚ãØ,‚àí] k:Sym kùî§‚Üíùî§
  [-,\cdots,-]_k : Sym^k \mathfrak{g} \to \mathfrak{g}


of degree -1, for each k‚àà‚Ñï +k \in \mathbb{N}_+.
Let {t a}\{t_a\} be a basis of ùî§\mathfrak{g} and {t a}\{t^a\} a dual basis of the degreewise dual ùî§ *\mathfrak{g}^*. Equip the Grassmann algebra Sym ‚Ä¢ùî§ *Sym^\bullet \mathfrak{g}^* with a derivation
d:Sym ‚Ä¢ùî§ *‚ÜíSym ‚Ä¢ùî§ *
  d : Sym^\bullet \mathfrak{g}^* \to Sym^\bullet \mathfrak{g}^*


defined on generators by
d:t a‚Ü¶‚àí‚àë k=1 ‚àû1k![t a 1,‚ãØ,t a k] k at a 1‚àß‚ãØ‚àßt a k.
  d : t^a 
    \mapsto 
    -
   \sum_{k = 1}^\infty 
    \frac{1}{k!}
   [t_{a_1}, \cdots, t_{a_k}]^a_k
   \,
   t^{a_1} \wedge \cdots \wedge t^{a_k}
  \,.


Here we take t at^a to be of the same degree as t at_a. Therefore this derivation has degree +1.
We compute the square d 2=d‚àòdd^2 = d \circ d:
ddt a =d(‚àí1)‚àë k=1 ‚àû1k![t a 1,‚ãØ,t a k] k at a 1‚àß‚ãØ‚àßt a k  =‚àë k,l=1 ‚àû1(k‚àí1)!l![[t b 1,‚ãØ,t b l],t a 2,‚ãØ,t a k] at b 1‚àß‚ãØ‚àßt b l‚àßt a 2‚àß‚ãØ‚àßt a k.
  \begin{aligned}
    d d t^a 
      &= 
    d (-1)\sum_{k = 1}^\infty 
    \frac{1}{k!}
    [t_{a_1}, \cdots, t_{a_k}]^a_k
   \,
   t^{a_1} \wedge \cdots \wedge t^{a_k}
    \\
    & = 
    \sum_{k,l = 1}^\infty
    \frac{1}{(k-1)! l!}
    [[t_{b_1}, \cdots, t_{b_l}], t_{a_2}, \cdots, t_{a_k}]^a
    \,
    t^{b_1} \wedge \cdots \wedge t^{b_l}  
    \wedge  
    t^{a_2} \wedge \cdots \wedge t^{a_{k}}
  \end{aligned}
  \,.


Here the wedge product on the right projects the nested bracket onto its graded-symmetric components. This is produced by summing over all permutations œÉ‚ààŒ£ k+l‚àí1\sigma \in \Sigma_{k+l-1} weighted by the Koszul-signature of the permutation:
‚ãØ=‚àë k,l=1 ‚àû1(k+l‚àí1)!‚àë œÉ‚ààŒ£ k+l‚àí1(‚àí1) sgn(œÉ)1(k‚àí1)!l![[t b 1,‚ãØ,t b l],t a 2,‚ãØ,t a k] at b 1‚àß‚ãØ‚àßt b l‚àßt a 2‚àß‚ãØ‚àßt a k.
  \cdots = 
    \sum_{k,l = 1}^\infty
    \frac{1}{(k+l-1)!}
    \sum_{\sigma \in \Sigma_{k+l-1}}
    (-1)^{sgn(\sigma)}
    \frac{1}{(k-1)! l!}
    [[t_{b_1}, \cdots, t_{b_l}], t_{a_2}, \cdots, t_{a_k}]^a
    \,
    t^{b_1} \wedge \cdots \wedge t^{b_l}  
    \wedge  
    t^{a_2} \wedge \cdots \wedge t^{a_{k}}
  \,.


The sum over all permutations decomposes into a sum over the (l,k‚àí1)(l,k-1)-unshuffles and a sum over permutations that act inside the first ll and the last (k‚àí1)(k-1) indices. By the graded-symmetry of the bracket, the latter do not change the value of the nested bracket. Since there are (k‚àí1)!l!(k-1)! l! many of them, we get
‚ãØ=‚àë k,l=1 ‚àû1(k+l‚àí1)!‚àë œÉ‚ààUnsh(l,k‚àí1)(‚àí1) sgn(œÉ)[[t a 1,‚ãØ,t a l],t a l+1,‚ãØ,t a k+l‚àí1]t a 1‚àß‚ãØ‚àßt a k+l‚àí1.
  \cdots 
    =
    \sum_{k,l = 1}^\infty
    \frac{1}{(k+l-1)!}
    \sum_{\sigma \in Unsh(l,k-1)}
    (-1)^{sgn(\sigma)}
    \left[\left[t_{a_1}, \cdots, t_{a_l}\right], t_{a_{l+1}}, \cdots, t_{a_{k+l-1}}\right]
    \,
    t^{a_1} \wedge \cdots \wedge t^{a_{k+l-1}}
  \,.


Therefore the condition d 2=0d^2 = 0 is equivalent to the condition
‚àë k+l=n‚àí1‚àë œÉ‚ààUnsh(l,k‚àí1)(‚àí1) sgn(œÉ)[[t a 1,‚ãØ,t a l],t a l+1,‚ãØ,t a k+l‚àí1]=0
    \sum_{k+l = n-1}
    \sum_{\sigma \in Unsh(l,k-1)}
    (-1)^{sgn(\sigma)}
    \left[\left[t_{a_1}, \cdots, t_{a_l}\right], t_{a_{l+1}}, \cdots, t_{a_{k+l-1}}\right]
  = 0


for all n‚àà‚Ñïn \in \mathbb{N} and all {t a i‚ààùî§}\{t_{a_i} \in \mathfrak{g}\}. This is equation (1) which says that {ùî§,{[‚àí,‚Ä¶,‚àí] k}}\{\mathfrak{g}, \{[-,\dots,-]_k\}\} is an L ‚àûL_\infty-algebra.
In terms of algebras over an operad
L ‚àûL_\infty-algebras are precisely the algebras over an operad of the cofibrant resolution of the Lie operad.
Ind-Conilpotency

Remark
(Pridham 10, remark 3.15, remark 3.13)
For ùî§\mathfrak{g} an L ‚àûL_\infty-algebra, then its CE chain dgc-coalgebra CE ‚Ä¢(ùî§)CE_\bullet(\mathfrak{g}) (above) is ind-conilpotent.
This means that CE ‚Ä¢(ùî§)CE_\bullet(\mathfrak{g}) is a filtered colimit of sub-dg-coalgebras which are conilpotent, in that for each of them there is n‚àà‚Ñïn \in \mathbb{N} such that their nn-fold coproduct vanishes. As such these are like ‚Äúco-local Artin algebras‚Äù.
Moreover, since every dg-coalgebra is the union of its finite-dimensonal subalgebras (see at dg-coalgebra the section As filtered colimits of finite-dimensional pieces), this means that CE ‚Ä¢(ùî§)CE_\bullet(\mathfrak{g}) is a filtered colimit of finite dimensional conilpotent coalgebras.
This implies that the dual Chevalley-Eilenberg cochain algebra CE ‚Ä¢(ùî§)CE^\bullet(\mathfrak{g}) is a filtered limit of finite-dimensional nilpotent dgc-algebras (actual local Artin algebras).

Model category structure
See model structure for L-‚àû algebras.
Relation to dg-Lie algebras
Every dg-Lie algebra is in an evident way an L ‚àûL_\infty-algebra. Dg-Lie algebras are precisely those L ‚àûL_\infty-algebras for which all nn-ary brackets for n>2n \gt 2 are trivial. These may be thought of as the strict L ‚àûL_\infty-algebras: those for which the Jacobi identity holds on the nose and all its possible higher coherences are trivial.

Theorem
Let kk be a field of characteristic 0 and write L ‚àûAlg kL_\infty Alg_k for the category of L‚àûL\infty-algebras over kk.
Then every object of L ‚àûAlg kL_\infty Alg_k is quasi-isomorphic to a dg-Lie algebra.
Moreover, one can find a functorial replacement: there is a functor
W:L ‚àûAlg k‚ÜíL ‚àûAlg k
  W : L_\infty Alg_k \to L_\infty Alg_k


such that for each ùî§‚ààL ‚àûAlg k\mathfrak{g} \in L_\infty Alg_k


W(ùî®)W(\mathfrak{k}) is a dg-Lie algebra;


there is a quasi-isomorphism
ùî§‚Üí‚âÉW(ùî§).
  \mathfrak{g} \stackrel{\simeq}{\to}
  W(\mathfrak{g})
  \,.




This appears for instance as (Kriz & May 1995, Cor. 1.6).
For more see at relation between L-‚àû algebras and dg-Lie algebras.
Relation to ‚àû\infty-Lie groupoids
In generalization to how a Lie algebra integrates to a Lie group, L ‚àûL_\infty-algebras integrate to ‚àû-Lie groups.
See
Lie integration
and
Lie integrated ‚àû-Lie groupoids.
A Lie group is a group with smooth structure. Lie groups form a category, LieGrp.

Definition
A Lie group is a smooth manifold whose underlying set of elements is equipped with the structure of a group such that the group multiplication and inverse-assigning functions are smooth functions.
In other words, a Lie group is a group object internal to the category SmthMfd of smooth manifolds.

Usually the smooth manifold is assumed to be defined over the real numbers and to be of finite dimension (f.d.), but extensions of the definition to some other ground fields or to -infinite-dimensional manifolds are also relevant, sometimes under other names (such as Fr√©chet Lie group when the underlying manifold is an infinite-dimensional Fr√©chet manifold).
A real Lie group is called a compact Lie group (or connected, simply connected Lie group, etc) if its underlying topological space is compact (or connected, simply connected, etc).
Every connected finite dimensional real Lie group is homeomorphic to a product of a compact Lie group (its maximal compact subgroup) and a Euclidean space.
Every abelian connected compact finite dimensional real Lie group is a torus (a product of circles T n=S 1√óS 1√ó‚Ä¶√óS 1T^n = S^1\times S^1 \times \ldots \times S^1).
There is an infinitesimal version of a Lie group, a so-called local Lie group, where the multiplication and the inverse are only partially defined, namely if the arguments of these operations are in a sufficiently small neighborhood of identity. There is a natural equivalence of local Lie groups by means of agreeing (topologically and algebraically) on a smaller neighborhood of the identity. The category of local Lie groups is equivalent to the category of connected and simply connected Lie groups.
The first order infinitesimal approximation to a Lie group is its Lie algebra.
Lie‚Äôs three theorems
Sophus Lie proved several theorems, known as Lie's three theorems, on the relationship between Lie algebras and Lie groups. Lie‚Äôs third theorem is about the equivalence of categories of finite-dimensional real Lie algebras and local Lie groups. Because √âlie Cartan extended this to a global integrability theorem, Lie‚Äôs third theorem is also called the Cartan-Lie theorem.
Lie subgroups


Proposition
(Cartan's closed subgroup theorem)
If H‚äÇGH \subset G is a closed subgroup of a (finite dimensional) Lie group, then HH is a sub-Lie group, hence a smooth submanifold such that its group operations are smooth functions with respect to the the submanifold smooth structure.


Classification


Proposition

Every connected finite-dimensional real Lie group is homeomorphic to a product of a compact Lie group and a Euclidean space. Every abelian connected compact f.d. real Lie group is a torus (a product of circles T n=S 1√óS 1√ó‚Ä¶√óS 1T^n = S^1\times S^1 \times \ldots \times S^1).

Different Lie group structures on a group
For GG a bare group (without smooth structure) there may be more than one way to equip it with the structure of a Lie group.

Example
As bare abelian groups, the Cartesian spaces ‚Ñù n\mathbb{R}^n are, for all nn, vector spaces over the rational numbers ‚Ñö\mathbb{Q} whose dimension is the cardinality of the continuum, 2 ‚Ñµ 02^{\aleph_0}.
Therefore these are all isomorphic as bare group. But equipped with their canonical Lie group structure (as in the Examples) they are of course not isomorphic.

Different topologies on a Lie group

Linus Kramer, The topology of a simple Lie group is essentially unique, (arXiv)


Abstract: We study locally compact group topologies on simple Lie groups. We show that the Lie group topology on such a group SS is very rigid: every ‚Äòabstract‚Äô isomorphism between SS and a locally compact and œÉ\sigma-compact group Œì\Gamma is automatically a homeomorphism, provided that SS is absolutely simple. If SS is complex, then non-continuous field automorphisms of the complex numbers have to be considered, but that is all.

Basic examples


The real line ‚Ñù\mathbb{R} with its standard smooth structure and the group operation being addition is a Lie group. So is every Cartesian space ‚Ñù n\mathbb{R}^n with the componentwise addition of real numbers.


The quotient of ‚Ñù\mathbb{R} by the subgroup of integers ‚Ñ§‚Ü™‚Ñù\mathbb{Z} \hookrightarrow \mathbb{R} is the circle group S 1=‚Ñù/‚Ñ§S^1 = \mathbb{R}/\mathbb{Z}. The quotient ‚Ñù n/‚Ñ§ n\mathbb{R}^n/\mathbb{Z}^n is the nn-dimensional torus.


The automorphism group of any Lie group is canonically itself a Lie group: the automorphism Lie group.


Classical Lie groups
The classical Lie groups include


the general linear group GL(n)GL(n)


the orthogonal group O(n)O(n) and special orthogonal group SO(n)SO(n);


the unitary group U(n)U(n) and special unitary group SU(n)SU(n);


the symplectic group Sp(2n)Sp(2n).

The notion of Lie 2-group is the generalization of the notion of Lie group as groups are generalized to 2-groups:
it is a smooth 2-group that happens to have a model given by a Lie groupoid equipped with the structure of a group object (in general only up to homotopy).
One general way to make the notion precise is as a special case of an smooth ‚àû-groupoid, namely a 1-truncated ‚àû-group object in ‚àû-stacks over the site CartSp/SmthMfd, possibly with some representability condition:
these are stacks on the site of smooth manifolds (representable by Lie groupoids and) equipped with group structure: ‚Äúgroup stacks‚Äù or ‚Äúgr-stacks‚Äù.
Special cases of this have simpler definitions. For instance a crossed module internal to Diff is a model for a strict and comparatively tame Lie 2-group.
Analogous to how the infinitesimal version of a Lie group is a Lie algebra, the infinitesimal version of a Lie 2-group is a Lie 2-algebra.
A smooth ‚àû\infty-groupoid is an ‚àû-groupoid equipped with cohesion in the form of smooth structure. Examples include smooth manifolds, Lie groups, Lie groupoids and generally Lie infinity-groupoids, but also for instance moduli spaces of differential forms, moduli stacks of principal connections and generally of cocycles in differential cohomology.
The (‚àû,1)-topos Smooth‚àûGrpdSmooth \infty Grpd of all smooth ‚àû\infty-groupoids is a cohesive (‚àû,1)-topos. It realizes a higher geometry version of differential geometry.
Many properties of smooth ‚àû\infty-groupoids are inherited from the underlying Euclidean-topological ‚àû-groupoids. See ETop‚àûGrpd for more.
There is a refinement of smooth ‚àû\infty-groupoids to synthetic differential ‚àû-groupoids. See SynthDiff‚àûGrpd for more on that.

Definition
For XX a smooth manifold, say an open cover {U i‚ÜíX}\{U_i \to X\} is a differentiably good open cover if each non-empty finite intersection of the U iU_i is diffeomorphic to a Cartesian space.


Proposition
Every paracompact smooth manifold admits a differentiably good open cover.


Proof
This is mathematical folklore. A detailed proof is given at good open cover.


Definition
Let SmoothMfd be the large site of paracompact smooth manifolds with smooth functions between them and equipped with the coverage of differentiably good open covers.



Proposition
This does indeed define a coverage. The Grothendieck topology that is generated from it is the standard open cover topology.



Proof
For {U i‚ÜíX}\{U_i \to X\} any open cover of a paracompact manifold also ‚àê iU i\coprod_i U_i is paracompact. Hence we may find a differentiably good open cover {K j‚Üí‚àê iU i}\{K_j \to \coprod_i U_i\}. This is then a refinement of the original open cover of XX.


Definition
Let CartSp smooth{}_{smooth} be the site of Cartesian spaces with smooth functions between them and equipped with the coverage of differentiably good open covers.

  \,.

We discuss the relation of Smooth‚àûGrpdSmooth\infty Grpd to other cohesive (‚àû,1)-toposes.
Continuous cohesion
The cohesive (‚àû,1)-topos ETop‚àûGrpd of Euclidean-topological ‚àû-groupoids has as site of definition CartSp top{}_{top}. There is a canonical forgetful functor

Truncations
