computation rule(y‚Ü¶a(y))(x)=a(x)(y \mapsto a(y))(x) = a(x)


Induced monad (state monad)
For each object SS the (internal hom ‚ä£\dashv tensor product)-adjunction induces a monad [S,S‚äó(‚àí)][S, S \otimes (-)]. In computer science this monad (in computer science) is called the state monad.
Stable splitting
In topology the stabilization/suspension spectrum Œ£ ‚àûMaps(X,A)\Sigma^\infty  Maps(X,A) of mapping spaces Maps(X,A)Maps(X,A) between suitable CW-complexes X,AX, A happens to decompose as a direct sum of spectra in a useful way, related to the expression of the Goodwillie derivatives of the functor Maps(X,‚àí)Maps(X,-).
For more on this see at stable splitting of mapping spaces.
In sets
In the category Set of sets, regarded as a cartesian monoidal category, the internal hom is given by function sets. This exists, by the discussion there, as soon as the foundational axioms are strong enough, for instance as soon as there are power objects, which is the special case of a function set into the 2-element set.
In simplicial sets
In the category sSet of simplicial sets, the internal hom between two simplicial sets X,YX,Y is given by the formula
[X,Y] n=Hom sSet(X√óŒî[n],Y),
  [X,Y]_n = Hom_{sSet}(X\times \Delta[n],Y)
  \,,


where Œî[n]\Delta[n] is the simplicial n-simplex. This [X,Y]‚ààsSet[X,Y] \in sSet is also called the function complex between XX and YY.
Since sSet‚âÉPSh(Œî)sSet \simeq PSh(\Delta) is the category of presheaves over the simplex category, this is a special case of internal homs in sheaf toposes, discussed below.
In a sheaf topos or (‚àû,1)(\infty,1)-sheaf (‚àû,1)(\infty,1)-topos
Let CC be a site. Let H=Sh(C)\mathbf{H} = Sh(C) be the sheaf topos over CC or in fact the (‚àû,1)-sheaf (‚àû,1)-topos. We discuss the internal hom of this regard as a cartesian monoidal category/cartesian monoidal (‚àû,1)-category.

Proposition
The sheaf topos H\mathbf{H} is a cartesian closed category / cartesian closed (‚àû,1)-category. In fact it is a locally cartesian closed category / locally cartesian closed (‚àû,1)-category.

Hence the internal hom exist.

Proposition
For X,Y‚ààHX, Y \in \mathbf{H} two objects, the internal hom-object
[X,Y]‚ààH
  [X,Y] \in \mathbf{H}


is the sheaf/(‚àû,1)-sheaf given by the assignment
[X,Y]:U‚Ü¶H(U√óX,Y),
  [X,Y] : U \mapsto \mathbf{H}(U \times X, Y)
  \,,


for all objects U‚ààCU \in C which on the right we regard under the Yoneda embedding/‚àû-Yoneda embedding U‚ààC‚Ü™YonedaHU \in C \stackrel{Yoneda}{\hookrightarrow} \mathbf{H}.
Here


U√óX‚ààHU \times X \in \mathbf{H} is the cartesian product of UU with XX


H(‚àí,‚àí)\mathbf{H}(-,-) is the hom set-functor / hom space-(‚àû,1)-functor of H\mathbf{H}.



See also at closed monoidal structure on presheaves.

Proof
By the Yoneda lemma/(‚àû,1)-Yoneda lemma we have natural equivalences
[X,Y](U)‚âÉH(U,[X,Y])
  [X,Y](U) \simeq \mathbf{H}(U , [X,Y])


and by the defining ((‚àí)√óX‚ä¢[X,‚àí])((-)\times X \vdash [X,-])adjunction this is naturally equivalent to
‚ãØ‚âÉH(U√óX,Y).
  \cdots \simeq \mathbf{H}(U \times X, Y)
  \,.



Remark
In the (homotopy-)type theory syntax of the internal language of H\mathbf{H} the internal hom [X,Y]‚ààH[X, Y] \in \mathbf{H} is the categorical semantics of the function type
‚ä¢(X‚ÜíY):Type.
  \vdash (X \to Y) : Type
  \,.



Proposition
For X,Y‚ààHX, Y \in \mathbf{H}, the evaluation map, def. ,
eval X,Y:[X,Y]√óX‚ÜíY
  eval_{X,Y} : [X,Y] \times X \to Y


is the morphism of sheaves which over each U‚ààCU \in C sends a morphism of sheaves Œ∏:H(‚àí,U)√óX(‚àí)‚ÜíY(‚àí)\theta : \mathbf{H}(-,U) \times X(-) \to Y(-) (which is the first component by prop. ) and an x‚ààH(U,X)x \in \mathbf{H}(U,X) to
eval X,Y(U):(Œ∏,x)‚Ü¶Œ∏ U(id U,x)‚ààY(U).
  eval_{X,Y}(U) : (\theta, x) \mapsto \theta_U(id_U, x) \in Y(U)
  \,.


See (MacLane-Moerdijk, p. 46).

Proposition
For X,Y,Z‚ààHX, Y, Z \in \mathbf{H} three objects of H\mathbf{H}, the canonical composition morphism, def. ,
‚àò X,Y,Z:[Y,Z]√ó[X,Y]‚Üí[X,Z]
  \circ_{X,Y,Z} : 
  [Y, Z] \times [X, Y] \to [X, Z]


is given by the morphism of presheaves/(‚àû,1)-presheaves whose component over U‚ààCU \in C is the morphism of sets/‚àû-groupoids
‚àò X,Y,Z(U):H(U√óX,Y)√óH(U√óY,Z)‚ÜíH(U√óX,Z)
  \circ_{X,Y,Z}(U)
  : 
  \mathbf{H}(U \times X, Y)
  \times
  \mathbf{H}(U \times Y, Z)
  \to 
  \mathbf{H}(U \times X, Z)


which sends a pair (f:U√óX‚ÜíY,g:U√óY‚ÜíZ)(f : U \times X \to Y, g : U \times Y \to Z) to the composite
‚àò X,Y,Z(U)(f,g)=U√óX‚Üí(Œî U,id X)U√óU√óX‚Üí(id U,f)U√óY‚ÜígZ,
  \circ_{X,Y,Z}(U)(f,g)
  = 
  U \times X 
  \stackrel{(\Delta_U, id_X)}{\to}
  U \times U \times X
  \stackrel{(id_U, f)}{\to}
  U \times Y 
  \stackrel{g}{\to}
  Z
  \,,


where Œî U:U‚ÜíU√óU\Delta_U : U \to U \times U is the diagonal morphism on UU.


Proof
By definition  the morphism is the adjunct of the double evaluation map
[Y,Z]√ó[X,Y]√óX‚ÜíZ.
  [Y,Z] \times [X,Y] \times X \to Z
  \,.


Since the cartesian product of two sheaves A,B‚ààHA, B \in \mathbf{H} is computed objectwise
A√óB:U‚Ü¶A(U)√óB(U)
  A \times B : U \mapsto A(U) \times B(U)


it follows that over each U‚ààCU \in C this double evaluation map is the morphism of sets/‚àû\infty-groupoids
[Y,Z](U)√ó[X,Y](U)√óX(U)‚ÜíZ(U)
  [Y,Z](U) \times [X,Y](U) \times X(U) \to Z(U)


hence by prop. 
H(U√óY,Z)√óH(U√óX,Y)√óH(U,X)‚ÜíH(U,Z),
  \mathbf{H}(U \times Y, Z) \times \mathbf{H}(U \times X, Y) \times 
  \mathbf{H}(U,X) \to \mathbf{H}(U,Z)
  \,,


where now by prop.  this is the external evaluation.


Remark
Intuitively this says that the composite of a UU-parameterized family of maps {f(u):X‚ÜíY|u‚ààU}\{f(u) :  X \to Y| u \in U\} with a UU-parameterized family of maps g(u):Y‚ÜíZ|u‚ààU{g(u) : Y \to Z| u \in U} is the UU-family given by the parameter-wise composite {g(u)‚àòf(u)|u‚ààU}\{g(u)\circ f(u) | u \in U\}.


Example
The internal automorphism group/automorphism ‚àû-group of an object X‚ààHX \in \mathbf{H} is the subobject
Aut(X)‚Ü™[X,X]
  \mathbf{Aut}(X) \hookrightarrow [X,X]


of the internal hom which is maximal subject to the property that the composition of prop.  becomes invertible.
The (homotopy-)type theory syntax for this is given by the type of equivalences in homotopy type theory
‚ä¢(X‚Üí‚âÉX):Type.
  \vdash (X \stackrel{\simeq}{\to} X) : Type
  \,.


In slice categories
Let H\mathbf{H} be a locally cartesian closed category. This means that for each object X‚ààHX \in \mathbf{H} the slice category H /X\mathbf{H}_{/X} is a cartesian closed category. The product in the slice is given by the fiber product over XX computed in H\mathbf{H}. Fairly detailed discussion of constructions of the internal hom in such slices H /X\mathbf{H}_{/X} is at locally cartesian closed category ‚Äì cartesian closure in terms of base change and dependent product.
We record some further properties

Proposition
For ùíû\mathcal{C} a locally cartesian closed category and f:X‚ÜíYf \colon X \to Y any morphism in ùíû\mathcal{C}, the inverse image f *f^* of the corresponding base change adjunction
ùíû /X‚Üí‚àè f‚Üêf *‚Üí‚àë fùíû /Y
  \mathcal{C}_{/X}
   \stackrel{\overset{\sum_f}{\to}}{\stackrel{\overset{f^*}{\leftarrow}}{\underset{\prod_f}{\to}}}
  \mathcal{C}_{/Y}


is a cartesian closed functor.

This is discussed in more detail at cartesian closed functor ‚Äì Examples.
So for A,B‚ààùíû /YA,B \in \mathcal{C}_{/Y} we have isomorphisms
f *[A,B]‚Üí‚âÉ[f *A,f *B]
  f^* \left[A,B\right] \stackrel{\simeq}{\to} \left[f^* A , f^* B\right]


between the image of the internal hom under f *f^* and the internal hom of the images of AA and BB separately.

Proposition
For H\mathbf{H} a locally cartesian closed category, f:X‚ÜíYf \colon X \to Y any morphism, and A,B‚ààH /XA, B \in \mathbf{H}_{/X} two objects in the slice over XX, there is a natural morphism (not in general an isomorphism)
‚àè f[A,B]‚Üí[‚àë fA,‚àë fB].
  \prod_f \left[A,B \right] \to \left[ \sum_f A, \sum_f B\right]
  \,.


Here are two ways to get this morphism:

Proof/Construction 1
For any object U‚ààH /YU \in \mathbf{H}_{/Y} we have a canonical morphism of hom sets
H /Y(U,‚àè f[A,B]) ‚âÉH /X(f *U,[A,B])  ‚âÉH /X(f *U√óA,B)  ‚ÜíH /Y(‚àë f(f *U√óA),‚àë fB)  ‚âÉFrob.Rec.H /Y(U√ó‚àë fA,‚àë fB)  ‚âÉH /Y(U,[‚àë fA,‚àë fB])
  \begin{aligned}
     \mathbf{H}_{/Y}( U, \prod_f [A,B] )
     & \simeq
     \mathbf{H}_{/X}( f^* U, [A,B] )
     \\
     & \simeq
     \mathbf{H}_{/X}(f^* U \times A, B)
     \\
     & \stackrel{}{\to}
    \mathbf{H}_{/Y}( \sum_f( f^* U \times A ), \sum_f B )
    \\
     & \stackrel{Frob.Rec.}{\simeq}
     \mathbf{H}_{/Y}( U \times \sum_f A , \sum_f B )
     \\
     & \simeq
    \mathbf{H}_{/Y}(U, [\sum_f A , \sum_f B])
  \end{aligned}


where the first and the last steps use adjunction properties, where the morphism in the middle is the component of the dependent sum functor, and where ‚ÄúFrob.Rec.‚Äù is Frobenius reciprocity.
Since this is natural in UU, the Yoneda lemma implies the claimed morphism.


Proof/Construction 2
There is the composite morphism
(f *‚àè f[A,B])√óA‚Üícounit√óid A[A,B]√óA‚ÜíevalB‚Üíunitf *‚àë fB
  \left(f^\ast \prod_f [A, B]\right) \times A \stackrel{counit \times id_A}{\to} [A, B] \times A \stackrel{eval}{\to} B \stackrel{unit}{\to} f^\ast \sum_f B

of the adjunction (co)units and the evaluation map of the internal hom. Its hom-adjunct is
A‚Üí[f *‚àè f[A,B],f *‚àë fB]‚âÖf *[‚àè f[A,B],‚àë fB],
  A \to [f^\ast \prod_f [A, B], f^\ast \sum_f B] \cong f^\ast [\prod_f [A, B], \sum_f B]
  \,,


using prop.  on the right. The hom-adjunct of that in turn is
‚àë fA‚Üí[‚àè f[A,B],‚àë fB]\sum_f A \to [\prod_f [A, B], \sum_f B]
and by symmetry the morphism that we are after:
‚àè f[A,B]‚Üí[‚àë fA,‚àë fB].
  \prod_f [A, B] \to [\sum_f A, \sum_f B]
  \,.



Remark
If YY is the terminal object (for simplicity), then the morphism of prop.  can be understood as follows: a global element of the dependent product ‚àè f[A,B]\prod_f [A,B] is given by a commuting diagram in H\mathbf{H} of the form
‚àë fA  ‚Üí  ‚àë fB  ‚Üò  ‚Üô   X.
  \array{
    \sum_f A &&\to&& \sum_f B
    \\
     & \searrow && \swarrow
     \\
     && X
  }
  \,.


The map in prop.  picks out the top horizontal morphism in this diagram.

For super vector spaces
The category sVectsVect of super vector spaces is the category of ‚Ñ§/2\mathbb{Z}/2-graded vector spaces. Thus, its objects are pairs of vector spaces (V +,V ‚àí)(V_+,V_-), with V +V_+ called the even part and V ‚àíV_- the odd part. The morphisms in sVectsVect are likewise pairs of linear maps, i.e. we define sVectsVect to be Vect√óVect=Vect ‚Ñ§/2Vect \times Vect = Vect^{\mathbb{Z}/2}, as usual for any sort of graded object. With this definition of the category sVectsVect, we capture the concepts of superalgebra and so on in succinct categorical terms.
Because the morphisms in sVectsVect send even things to even things and odd things to odd things, they are sometimes called even linear maps, and one may write
sVect(V,W)=EvenLin(V,W).
 sVect(V, W) = Even Lin(V,W).


Note that sVectsVect is enriched over VectVect, i.e. these hom-sets are vector spaces.
Occasionally, however, one does need to refer to the odd linear maps, which send even things to odd things and odd things to even things. That is, an odd linear map V‚ÜíWV\to W is a pair of linear maps V +‚ÜíW ‚àíV_+ \to W_- and V ‚àí‚ÜíW +V_-\to W_+. The internal-hom in sVectsVect allows us to capture these as well: it is the following super vector space:
[V,W] +=EvenLin(V,W)[V,W] ‚àí=OddLin(V,W).
  [V,W]_+ = Even Lin(V,W) \qquad
  [V,W]_- = Odd Lin(V,W).


With this definition, sVectsVect becomes a closed monoidal category.
We can equivalently regard a super vector spaces (V +,V ‚àí)(V_+,V_-) as being the direct sum vector space V +‚äïV ‚àíV_+ \oplus V_- equipped with this direct sum decomposition. If we view the internal-hom [V,W][V,W] in this way as well, then we have
[V,W]=EvenLin(V,W)‚äïOddLin(V,W)=Lin(V,W).
 [V, W] = Even Lin(V,W) \oplus Odd Lin(V,W) = Lin(V,W).


In other words, any linear map between these ‚Äúsummed‚Äù super vector spaces decomposes uniquely as the sum of an even linear map and an odd one.
For Banach spaces
A similar thing happens in the category BanBan of Banach spaces and short linear operators. The external hom consists of only the short linear maps (those bounded by 11):
Ban(V,W)={f:Lin(V,W)|‚Äñf‚Äñ‚â§1}. Ban(V,W) = \{ f\colon Lin(V,W) \;|\; {\|f\|} \leq 1 \} .
This definition of morphism recovers the most specific notion of isomorphism of Banach spaces, as well as defining the product and coproduct as the direct sum completed with p=‚àûp = \infty or p=1p = 1 respectively.
But the internal hom is the Banach space of all bounded linear maps:
[V,W]={f:Lin(V,W)|‚Äñf‚Äñ<‚àû}. [V,W] = \{ f\colon Lin(V,W) \;|\; {\|f\|} \lt \infty \} .
This is a Banach space and makes BanBan into a closed category.
A category consists of a collection of objects together with morphisms between these objects. Thus, naively, we may think of objects as the ‚Äòelements‚Äô of a category.
More generally, in higher category theory the objects of an (n,r)(n,r)-category are the 00-dimensional cells of that structure, the 00-morphisms.
Explicitly
A section of a morphism f:A‚ÜíBf : A \to B in some category is a right-inverse: a morphism œÉ:B‚ÜíA\sigma : B \to A such that
f‚àòœÉ:B‚ÜíœÉA‚ÜífB
  f \circ \sigma : B \stackrel{\sigma}{\to} A \stackrel{f}{\to} B


equals the identity morphism on BB.
Typically A‚ÜífBA \stackrel{f}{\to} B is thought of as a bundle and then one speaks of sections of bundles. For topological bundles one considers continuous sections, for smooth bundles smooth sections, etc.
In terms of dependent product
In a locally cartesian closed category ùíû\mathcal{C}, regard the morphism f:A‚ÜíBf\colon A \to B as an object [f]‚ààùíû /B[f] \in \mathcal{C}_{/B} in the slice category over BB. Then there is the dependent product
‚àèB[f]‚ààùíû.
  \underset{B}{\prod} [f] \in \mathcal{C}
  \,.


This is the space of sections of ff. A single section œÉ\sigma is a global element in here
œÉ:*‚Üí‚àèB[f].
  \sigma \colon \ast \to \underset{B}{\prod} [f]
  \,.


See at dependent product ‚Äì In terms of spaces of sections for more on this.
A natural topology on mapping spaces of continuous functions, important because of its role in exhibiting locally compact topological spaces to be exponentiable, as demonstrated below, culminating in Corollary .
The compact-open topology on the set of continuous functions X‚ÜíYX \to Y is generated by the subbasis of subsets U K‚äÇC(X,Y)U^K \subset C(X,Y) that map a given compact subspace K‚äÇXK \subset X to a given open subset U‚äÇYU \subset Y, whence the name.
When restricting to continuous functions between compactly generated topological spaces one usually modifies this definition to a subbase of open subsets U œï(K)U^{\phi(K)}, where now œï(K)\phi(K) is the image of a compact topological space under any continuous function œï:K‚ÜíX\phi \colon K \to X. This definition gives a cartesian internal hom in the category of compactly generated topological spaces (see also at convenient category of topological spaces).
The two definitions agree when the domain XX is a compactly generated Hausdorff space, but not in general. Beware that texts on compactly generated spaces nevertheless commonly say ‚Äúcompact-open topology‚Äù for the second definition.

Notation
Let (X,ùí™ X)(X, \mathcal{O}_{X}) and (Y,ùí™ Y)(Y, \mathcal{O}_{Y}) be topological spaces. We denote by Y XY^{X} the set of continuous maps from (X,ùí™ X)(X,\mathcal{O}_{X}) to (Y,ùí™ Y)(Y, \mathcal{O}_{Y}).


Remark
Other common notations for Y XY^{X} are Map(X,Y)Map(X,Y) or C(X,Y)C(X,Y).


Notation
Let (X,ùí™ X)(X, \mathcal{O}_{X}) be a topological space. We denote by ùí™ X c\mathcal{O}^{c}_{X} the set of subsets of XX which are compact with respect to ùí™ X\mathcal{O}_{X}.


Notation
Let (X,ùí™ X)(X, \mathcal{O}_{X}) be a topological space. Let AA be a subset of XX. We denote by A¬Ø\overline{A} the topological closure of AA in XX with respect to ùí™ X\mathcal{O}_{X}.


Definition
A topological space (X,ùí™ X)(X, \mathcal{O}_{X}) is locally compact if the set of compact neighbourhoods of points of XX form a neighbourhood basis of XX. That is to say: for every x‚ààXx \in X and every neighbourhood NN of xx, there is a V‚ààùí™ X cV \in \mathcal{O}^{c}_{X} and a U‚ààùí™ XU \in \mathcal{O}_{X} such that x‚ààU‚äÇV‚äÇNx \in U \subset V \subset N.


Remark
There are many variations on this definition, which can be found at locally compact space. These are all equivalent if (X,ùí™ X)(X, \mathcal{O}_{X}) is Hausdorff. We do not however make the assumption that (X,ùí™ X)(X, \mathcal{O}_{X}) is Hausdorff.


Notation
Let (X,ùí™ X)(X, \mathcal{O}_{X}) and (Y,ùí™ Y)(Y, \mathcal{O}_{Y}) be topological spaces. Given A‚ààùí™ X cA \in \mathcal{O}^{c}_{X} and U‚ààùí™ YU \in \mathcal{O}_{Y}, we denote by M A,UM_{A,U} the set of continuous maps f:X‚ÜíYf : X \rightarrow Y such that f(A)‚äÇUf(A) \subset U.


Definition
Let (X,ùí™ X)(X, \mathcal{O}_{X}) and (Y,ùí™ Y)(Y, \mathcal{O}_{Y}) be topological spaces. The compact-open topology on Y XY^{X} is that with sub-basis given by the set of sets M A,UM_{A,U} such that A‚ààùí™ X cA \in \mathcal{O}^{c}_{X} and U‚ààùí™ YU \in \mathcal{O}_{Y}.


Notation
Let (X,ùí™ X)(X, \mathcal{O}_{X}) and (Y,ùí™ Y)(Y, \mathcal{O}_{Y}) be topological spaces. We shall denote the compact-open topology (def. ) on Y XY^{X} by ùí™ Y X\mathcal{O}_{Y^{X}}.

Explicitly
A section of a morphism f:A‚ÜíBf : A \to B in some category is a right-inverse: a morphism œÉ:B‚ÜíA\sigma : B \to A such that
f‚àòœÉ:B‚ÜíœÉA‚ÜífB
  f \circ \sigma : B \stackrel{\sigma}{\to} A \stackrel{f}{\to} B


equals the identity morphism on BB.
Typically A‚ÜífBA \stackrel{f}{\to} B is thought of as a bundle and then one speaks of sections of bundles. For topological bundles one considers continuous sections, for smooth bundles smooth sections, etc.
In terms of dependent product
In a locally cartesian closed category ùíû\mathcal{C}, regard the morphism f:A‚ÜíBf\colon A \to B as an object [f]‚ààùíû /B[f] \in \mathcal{C}_{/B} in the slice category over BB. Then there is the dependent product
‚àèB[f]‚ààùíû.
  \underset{B}{\prod} [f] \in \mathcal{C}
  \,.


This is the space of sections of ff. A single section œÉ\sigma is a global element in here
œÉ:*‚Üí‚àèB[f].
  \sigma \colon \ast \to \underset{B}{\prod} [f]
  \,.


See at dependent product ‚Äì In terms of spaces of sections for more on this.
For ùíû\mathcal{C} a category and X,Y‚ààùíûX, Y \in \mathcal{C} two objects, the internal hom [X,Y]‚ààùíû[X,Y] \in \mathcal{C} from XX to YY is, if it exists, another object of ùíû\mathcal{C} which behaves like the ‚Äúobject of morphisms‚Äù from XX to YY. In other words it is, if it exists, an internal version of the ordinary hom set ùíû(X,Y)‚ààSet\mathcal{C}(X, Y) \in Set or more generally hom object ùíû(X,Y)‚ààùí±\mathcal{C}(X, Y) \in \mathcal{V} of a locally small category or ùí±\mathcal{V}-enriched category.
One way to make this precise starts by mimicking a property of the function set [X,Y]={f:X‚ÜíY}[X,Y] = \{f : X \to Y\} of functions between two sets XX and YY: this set is characterized by the fact that for any other set SS, the functions S‚Üí[X,Y]S \to [X,Y] are in natural bijection with the functions S√óX‚ÜíYS \times X \to Y out of the cartesian product of SS with XX. That is: for each set XX, the functor (‚àí)√óX(-) \times X has a right adjoint, given by the construction [X,‚àí][X,-].
One can verbalize this thus: taking the cartesian product with the set XX is left-adjoint to taking the set of all functions with domain XX.
This, then, is, generally, the definition of internal hom in any cartesian monoidal category or in fact in any monoidal category (ùíû,‚äó)(\mathcal{C}, \otimes): the right adjoint [X,‚àí][X,-] to the given tensor product functor (‚àí)‚äóX(-)\otimes X for all objects XX. It may or may not exist. If it exists, one says that (ùíû,‚äó)(\mathcal{C}, \otimes) is a closed monoidal category. Explicity, the condition is that there is an isomorphism(bijection)
ùíû(A,[X,Z])‚Üí‚âÉùíû(A‚äóX,Z)
  \mathcal{C}(A, [X,Z]) \stackrel{\simeq}{\to} \mathcal{C}(A \otimes X, Z)


which is natural in all three variables. (The rightward map here is often called currying, especially in a closed monoidal category (and more especially for the Œª\lambda-calculus).)
In particular this implies that in a closed monoidal category the external hom is re-obtained from the internal hom as its set of generalized elements out of the tensor unit I‚ààùíûI \in \mathcal{C} in that
I‚Üí[X,Y]X‚ÜíY
  \frac{I \to [X,Y]}{X \to Y}


using that I‚äóX‚âÉXI \otimes X \simeq X by definition of the tensor unit.
Here ‚Äúclosed‚Äù in ‚Äúclosed monoidal category‚Äù is in the sense that forming ‚Äúhom-sets‚Äù does not lead ‚Äúout of the category‚Äù. In fact the internal hom of a cartesian monoidal category is indeed the hom as seen in the internal logic of that category (the function type).
More generally, one can consider objects that satisfy some basic universal properties that an internal hom should satisfy even in the absence of a monoidal structure. If such objects exist one speaks therefore just of a closed category. Every closed category may be seen as a category enriched over itself. Accordingly, an internal hom is after all a special case of a hom-object, for the special case of this enrichment over itself.

Definition
(internal hom)
Let (ùíû,‚äó)(\mathcal{C}, \otimes) be a symmetric monoidal category. An internal hom in ùíû\mathcal{C} is a functor
[‚àí,‚àí]:ùíû op√óùíû‚Üíùíû
  [-,-] : \mathcal{C}^{op} \times \mathcal{C} \to \mathcal{C}


such that for every object X‚ààùíûX \in \mathcal{C} we have a pair of adjoint functors
((‚àí)‚äóX‚ä£[X,‚àí]):ùíû‚Üíùíû.
  ((-) \otimes X \dashv [X, -]) : \mathcal{C} \to \mathcal{C}
  \,.


If this exists, (ùíû,‚äó)(\mathcal{C}, \otimes) is called a closed monoidal category.


Remark
If the monoidal category ùíû\mathcal{C} in Def.  is not symmetric, there is instead a concept of left- and right-internal hom.

Evaluation map
Let (ùíû,‚äó)(\mathcal{C}, \otimes) be a symmetric closed monoidal category (Def. ).

Definition
For X,Y‚ààùíûX,Y \in \mathcal{C} two objects, the evaluation map
eval X,Y:[X,Y]‚äóX‚ÜíY
  eval_{X,Y} : [X,Y] \otimes X \to Y


is the ((‚àí)‚äóX‚ä£[X,‚àí])((-)\otimes X \dashv [X,-])-adjunct of the identity id [X,Y]:[X,Y]‚Üí[X,Y]id_{[X,Y]} : [X,Y] \to [X,Y].


Remark
If ùíû\mathcal{C} is specifically a locally cartesian closed category, then in terms of the type theory internal language of ùíû\mathcal{C} the evaluation map is the categorical semantics of the dependent type which in type theory syntax is
f:X‚ÜíY,x:X‚ä¢f(x):Y,
  f \colon X \to Y,\; x \colon X 
    \;\vdash\; 
   f(x) \colon Y
  \,,


with function application on the right.

Composition map
Let (ùíû,√ó)(\mathcal{C}, \times) be a symmetric closed monoidal category (Def. )

Definition
For X,Y,Z‚ààùíûX, Y, Z \in \mathcal{C} three objects, the composition morphism
‚àò X,Y,Z:[Y,Z]√ó[X,Y]‚Üí[X,Z]
  \circ_{X,Y,Z} : 
  [Y, Z]
  \times
  [X, Y]
  \to 
  [X, Z]


is the ((‚àí)√óX‚ä£[X,‚àí])((-)\times X \dashv [X,-])-adjunct of the following composite of two evaluation maps, def. :
[Y,Z]√ó[X,Y]√óX‚Üí(id [Y,Z],eval X,Y)[Y,Z]√óY‚Üíeval Y,ZZ.
  [Y, Z] \times [X , Y] \times X 
    \stackrel{(id_{[Y,Z]}, eval_{X,Y})}{\to}
  [Y,Z] \times Y
    \stackrel{eval_{Y,Z}}{\to}
  Z
  \,.


Basic properties
The internal homs in a symmetric closed monoidal category (Def. ) happen to share all the key abstract properties of ordinary (‚Äúexternal‚Äù) hom-functors, even though this is not completely manifest from Def. :

Proposition
(internal hom bifunctor)
Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a symmetric monoidal category such that for each object X‚ààùíûX \in \mathcal{C} the functor X‚äó(‚àí)X \otimes (-) has a right adjoint [X,‚àí][X,-]. Then this is already equivalent to Def. , in that there is a unique functor out of the product categoryof ùíû\mathcal{C} with its opposite category
[‚àí,‚àí]:ùíû op√óùíû‚ü∂ùíû
  [-,-]
  \;\colon\;
  \mathcal{C}^{op} \times \mathcal{C}
    \longrightarrow
  \mathcal{C}


such that for each X‚ààùíûX \in \mathcal{C} it coincides with the internal hom [X,‚àí][X,-] as a functor in the second variable, and such that there is a natural isomorphism
Hom(X,[Y,Z])‚âÉHom(X‚äóY,Z)
  Hom(X, [Y,Z])
  \;\simeq\;
  Hom(X \otimes Y, Z)


which is natural not only in XX and ZZ, but also in YY.


Proof
We have a natural isomorphism for each fixed YY, and hence in particular for fixed YY and fixed ZZ. With this the statement follows directly by this prop. at adjoint functor.

In fact the 3-variable adjunction from Prop.  even holds internally:

Proposition
(internal tensor/hom-adjunction)
In a closed monoidal category (def. ) there are natural isomorphisms
[X‚äóY,Z]‚âÉ[X,[Y,Z]]
  [X \otimes Y, Z]
   \;\simeq\;
  [X, [Y,Z]]


whose image under Hom ùíû(1,‚àí)Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(1,-) are the defining natural bijections of Prop. .


Proof
Let A‚ààùíûA \in \mathcal{C} be any object. By applying the natural bijections from Prop. , there are composite natural bijections
Hom ùíû(A,[X‚äóY,Z]) ‚âÉHom ùíû(A‚äó(X‚äóY),Z)  ‚âÉHom ùíû((A‚äóX)‚äóY,Z)  ‚âÉHom ùíû(A‚äóX,[Y,Z])  ‚âÉHom ùíû(A,[X,[Y,Z]])
  \begin{aligned}
    Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(A , [X \otimes Y, Z])
    & \simeq
    Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(A \otimes (X \otimes Y), Z)
    \\
    & \simeq
    Hom_{\mathcal{C}}((A \otimes X)\otimes Y, Z)
    \\
    & \simeq
    Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(A \otimes X, [Y,Z])
    \\
    & \simeq
    Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(A, [X, [Y,Z]])
  \end{aligned}


Since this holds for all AA, the fully faithfulness of the Yoneda embedding says that there is an isomorphism [X‚äóY,Z]‚âÉ[X,[Y,Z]][ X\otimes Y, Z ] \simeq [X, [Y,Z]]. Moreover, by taking A=1A = 1 in the above and using the left unitor isomorphisms A‚äó(X‚äóY)‚âÉX‚äóYA \otimes (X \otimes Y) \simeq X \otimes Y and A‚äóX‚âÉXA\otimes X \simeq X we get a commuting diagram
Hom ùíû(1,[X‚äóY,Z]) ‚ü∂‚âÉ Hom ùíû(1,[X,[Y,Z]])  ‚âÉ‚Üì  ‚Üì ‚âÉ Hom ùíû(X‚äóY,Z) ‚ü∂‚âÉ Hom ùíû(X,[Y,Z]).
  \array{
    Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(1, [X\otimes Y, Z ])
      &\overset{\simeq}{\longrightarrow}&
    Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(1, [X, [Y,Z]])
    \\
    {}^{\mathllap{\simeq}}\downarrow
      &&
    \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\simeq}}
    \\
    Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(X \otimes Y, Z)
     &\overset{\simeq}{\longrightarrow}&
    Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(X, [Y,Z])
  }
  \,.


Also the key respect of hom-functors for limits is inherited by internal hom-functors:

Proposition
(internal hom-functor preserves limits)
Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a symmetric closed monoidal category with internal hom-bifunctor [‚àí,‚àí][-,-] (Prop. ). Then this bifunctor preserves limits in the second variable, and sends colimits in the first variable to limits:
[X,lim‚üµj‚ààùí•Y(j)]‚âÉlim‚üµj‚ààùí•[X,Y(j)]
  [X, \underset{\underset{j \in \mathcal{J}}{\longleftarrow}}{\lim} Y(j)]
  \;\simeq\;
  \underset{\underset{j \in \mathcal{J}}{\longleftarrow}}{\lim} [X, Y(j)]


and
[lim‚ü∂j‚ààùí•Y(j),X]‚âÉlim‚üµj‚ààùí•[Y(j),X]
  [\underset{\underset{j \in \mathcal{J}}{\longrightarrow}}{\lim} Y(j),X]
  \;\simeq\;
  \underset{\underset{j \in \mathcal{J}}{\longleftarrow}}{\lim} [Y(j),X]  



Proof
For X‚ààùíûX \in \mathcal{C} any object, [X,‚àí][X,-] is a right adjoint by definition, and hence preserves limits by adjoints preserve (co-)limits.
For the other case, let Y:‚Ñí‚ÜíùíûY \;\colon\; \mathcal{L} \to \mathcal{C} be a diagram in ùíû\mathcal{C}, and let C‚ààùíûC \in \mathcal{C} be any object. Then there are isomorphisms
Hom ùíû(C,[lim‚ü∂j‚ààùí•Y(j),X]) ‚âÉHom ùíû(C‚äólim‚ü∂j‚ààùí•Y(j),X)  ‚âÉHom ùíû(lim‚ü∂j‚ààùí•(C‚äóY(j)),X)  ‚âÉlim‚üµj‚ààùí•Hom ùíû((C‚äóY(j)),X)  ‚âÉlim‚üµj‚ààùí•Hom ùíû(C,[Y(j),X])  ‚âÉHom ùíû(C,lim‚üµj‚ààùí•[Y(j),X])
  \begin{aligned}
    Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(C, [ \underset{\underset{j \in \mathcal{J}}{\longrightarrow}}{\lim} Y(j), X ] )
    & \simeq
    Hom_{\mathcal{C}}( C \otimes \underset{\underset{j \in \mathcal{J}}{\longrightarrow}}{\lim} Y(j), X )
    \\
    & \simeq
    Hom_{\mathcal{C}}( \underset{\underset{j \in \mathcal{J}}{\longrightarrow}}{\lim} (C \otimes Y(j)), X )   
    \\
    & \simeq
    \underset{\underset{j \in \mathcal{J}}{\longleftarrow}}{\lim}
    Hom_{\mathcal{C}}( (C \otimes Y(j)), X )    
    \\
    & \simeq
    \underset{\underset{j \in \mathcal{J}}{\longleftarrow}}{\lim}
    Hom_{\mathcal{C}}( C, [Y(j), X] )    
    \\
    & \simeq
    Hom_{\mathcal{C}}( C, \underset{\underset{j \in \mathcal{J}}{\longleftarrow}}{\lim} [Y(j), X] )    
  \end{aligned}


which are natural in C‚ààùíûC \in \mathcal{C}, where we used that the ordinary hom-functor respects (co)limits as shown (see at hom-functor preserves limits), and that the left adjoint C‚äó(‚àí)C \otimes (-) preserves colimits (see at adjoints preserve (co-)limits).
Hence by the fully faithfulness of the Yoneda embedding, there is an isomorphism
[lim‚ü∂j‚ààùí•Y(j),X]‚ü∂‚âÉlim‚üµj‚ààùí•[Y(j),X].
  \left[ \underset{\underset{j \in \mathcal{J}}{\longrightarrow}}{\lim} Y(j), X \right]  
  \overset{\simeq}{\longrightarrow}
  \underset{\underset{j \in \mathcal{J}}{\longleftarrow}}{\lim} [Y(j), X] 
  \,.


Relation to function types

Induced monad (state monad)
For each object SS the (internal hom ‚ä£\dashv tensor product)-adjunction induces a monad [S,S‚äó(‚àí)][S, S \otimes (-)]. In computer science this monad (in computer science) is called the state monad.
Stable splitting
In topology the stabilization/suspension spectrum Œ£ ‚àûMaps(X,A)\Sigma^\infty  Maps(X,A) of mapping spaces Maps(X,A)Maps(X,A) between suitable CW-complexes X,AX, A happens to decompose as a direct sum of spectra in a useful way, related to the expression of the Goodwillie derivatives of the functor Maps(X,‚àí)Maps(X,-).
For more on this see at stable splitting of mapping spaces.
In sets
In the category Set of sets, regarded as a cartesian monoidal category, the internal hom is given by function sets. This exists, by the discussion there, as soon as the foundational axioms are strong enough, for instance as soon as there are power objects, which is the special case of a function set into the 2-element set.
In simplicial sets
In the category sSet of simplicial sets, the internal hom between two simplicial sets X,YX,Y is given by the formula
[X,Y] n=Hom sSet(X√óŒî[n],Y),
  [X,Y]_n = Hom_{sSet}(X\times \Delta[n],Y)
  \,,


where Œî[n]\Delta[n] is the simplicial n-simplex. This [X,Y]‚ààsSet[X,Y] \in sSet is also called the function complex between XX and YY.
Since sSet‚âÉPSh(Œî)sSet \simeq PSh(\Delta) is the category of presheaves over the simplex category, this is a special case of internal homs in sheaf toposes, discussed below.
In a sheaf topos or (‚àû,1)(\infty,1)-sheaf (‚àû,1)(\infty,1)-topos
Let CC be a site. Let H=Sh(C)\mathbf{H} = Sh(C) be the sheaf topos over CC or in fact the (‚àû,1)-sheaf (‚àû,1)-topos. We discuss the internal hom of this regard as a cartesian monoidal category/cartesian monoidal (‚àû,1)-category.

Proposition
The sheaf topos H\mathbf{H} is a cartesian closed category / cartesian closed (‚àû,1)-category. In fact it is a locally cartesian closed category / locally cartesian closed (‚àû,1)-category.

Hence the internal hom exist.

Proposition

[X,Y]‚ààH

  \,,


for all objects U‚ààCU \in C which on the right we regard under the Yoneda embedding/‚àû-Yoneda embedding U‚ààC‚Ü™YonedaHU \in C \stackrel{Yoneda}{\hookrightarrow} \mathbf{H}.
Here


U√óX‚ààHU \times X \in \mathbf{H} is the cartesian product of UU with XX


H(‚àí,‚àí)\mathbf{H}(-,-) is the hom set-functor / hom space-(‚àû,1)-functor of H\mathbf{H}.



See also at closed monoidal structure on presheaves.

Proof

[X,Y](U)‚âÉH(U,[X,Y])

and by the defining ((‚àí)√óX‚ä¢[X,‚àí])((-)\times X \vdash [X,-])adjunction this is naturally equivalent to

  \cdots \simeq \mathbf{H}(U \times X, Y)

Remark
In the (homotopy-)type theory syntax of the internal language of H\mathbf{H} the internal hom [X,Y]‚ààH[X, Y] \in \mathbf{H} is the categorical semantics of the function type
‚ä¢(X‚ÜíY):Type.
  \vdash (X \to Y) : Type
  \,.



Proposition

eval X,Y:[X,Y]√óX‚ÜíY

is the morphism of sheaves which over each U‚ààCU \in C sends a morphism of sheaves Œ∏:H(‚àí,U)√óX(‚àí)‚ÜíY(‚àí)\theta : \mathbf{H}(-,U) \times X(-) \to Y(-) (which is the first component by prop. ) and an x‚ààH(U,X)x \in \mathbf{H}(U,X) to

  eval_{X,Y}(U) : (\theta, x) \mapsto \theta_U(id_U, x) \in Y(U)

See (MacLane-Moerdijk, p. 46).

Proposition
For X,Y,Z‚ààHX, Y, Z \in \mathbf{H} three objects of H\mathbf{H}, the canonical composition morphism, def. ,
‚àò X,Y,Z:[Y,Z]√ó[X,Y]‚Üí[X,Z]
  \circ_{X,Y,Z} : 
  [Y, Z] \times [X, Y] \to [X, Z]


is given by the morphism of presheaves/(‚àû,1)-presheaves whose component over U‚ààCU \in C is the morphism of sets/‚àû-groupoids

  \mathbf{H}(U \times Y, Z)
  \to

which sends a pair (f:U√óX‚ÜíY,g:U√óY‚ÜíZ)(f : U \times X \to Y, g : U \times Y \to Z) to the composite
‚àò X,Y,Z(U)(f,g)=U√óX‚Üí(Œî U,id X)U√óU√óX‚Üí(id U,f)U√óY‚ÜígZ,
  \circ_{X,Y,Z}(U)(f,g)
  = 
  U \times X 
  \stackrel{(\Delta_U, id_X)}{\to}
  U \times U \times X
  \stackrel{(id_U, f)}{\to}
  U \times Y 
  \stackrel{g}{\to}
  Z
  \,,


where Œî U:U‚ÜíU√óU\Delta_U : U \to U \times U is the diagonal morphism on UU.


Proof
By definition  the morphism is the adjunct of the double evaluation map
[Y,Z]√ó[X,Y]√óX‚ÜíZ.
  [Y,Z] \times [X,Y] \times X \to Z
  \,.


Since the cartesian product of two sheaves A,B‚ààHA, B \in \mathbf{H} is computed objectwise
A√óB:U‚Ü¶A(U)√óB(U)
  A \times B : U \mapsto A(U) \times B(U)


it follows that over each U‚ààCU \in C this double evaluation map is the morphism of sets/‚àû\infty-groupoids
[Y,Z](U)√ó[X,Y](U)√óX(U)‚ÜíZ(U)

hence by prop. 
H(U√óY,Z)√óH(U√óX,Y)√óH(U,X)‚ÜíH(U,Z),
  \mathbf{H}(U \times Y, Z) \times \mathbf{H}(U \times X, Y) \times 
  \mathbf{H}(U,X) \to \mathbf{H}(U,Z)
  \,,


where now by prop.  this is the external evaluation.


Remark
Intuitively this says that the composite of a UU-parameterized family of maps {f(u):X‚ÜíY|u‚ààU}\{f(u) :  X \to Y| u \in U\} with a UU-parameterized family of maps g(u):Y‚ÜíZ|u‚ààU{g(u) : Y \to Z| u \in U} is the UU-family given by the parameter-wise composite {g(u)‚àòf(u)|u‚ààU}\{g(u)\circ f(u) | u \in U\}.


Example
The internal automorphism group/automorphism ‚àû-group of an object X‚ààHX \in \mathbf{H} is the subobject

  \mathbf{Aut}(X) \hookrightarrow [X,X]


of the internal hom which is maximal subject to the property that the composition of prop.  becomes invertible.

‚ä¢(X‚Üí‚âÉX):Type.
  \vdash (X \stackrel{\simeq}{\to} X) : Type
  \,.


In slice categories
Let H\mathbf{H} be a locally cartesian closed category. This means that for each object X‚ààHX \in \mathbf{H} the slice category H /X\mathbf{H}_{/X} is a cartesian closed category. The product in the slice is given by the fiber product over XX computed in H\mathbf{H}. Fairly detailed discussion of constructions of the internal hom in such slices H /X\mathbf{H}_{/X} is at locally cartesian closed category ‚Äì cartesian closure in terms of base change and dependent product.
We record some further properties

Proposition
For ùíû\mathcal{C} a locally cartesian closed category and f:X‚ÜíYf \colon X \to Y any morphism in ùíû\mathcal{C}, the inverse image f *f^* of the corresponding base change adjunction
ùíû /X‚Üí‚àè f‚Üêf *‚Üí‚àë fùíû /Y
  \mathcal{C}_{/X}
   \stackrel{\overset{\sum_f}{\to}}{\stackrel{\overset{f^*}{\leftarrow}}{\underset{\prod_f}{\to}}}
  \mathcal{C}_{/Y}


is a cartesian closed functor.

This is discussed in more detail at cartesian closed functor ‚Äì Examples.
So for A,B‚ààùíû /YA,B \in \mathcal{C}_{/Y} we have isomorphisms
f *[A,B]‚Üí‚âÉ[f *A,f *B]
  f^* \left[A,B\right] \stackrel{\simeq}{\to} \left[f^* A , f^* B\right]


between the image of the internal hom under f *f^* and the internal hom of the images of AA and BB separately.

Proposition
For H\mathbf{H} a locally cartesian closed category, f:X‚ÜíYf \colon X \to Y any morphism, and A,B‚ààH /XA, B \in \mathbf{H}_{/X} two objects in the slice over XX, there is a natural morphism (not in general an isomorphism)
‚àè f[A,B]‚Üí[‚àë fA,‚àë fB].
  \prod_f \left[A,B \right] \to \left[ \sum_f A, \sum_f B\right]
  \,.


Here are two ways to get this morphism:

Proof/Construction 1
For any object U‚ààH /YU \in \mathbf{H}_{/Y} we have a canonical morphism of hom sets
H /Y(U,‚àè f[A,B]) ‚âÉH /X(f *U,[A,B])  ‚âÉH /X(f *U√óA,B)  ‚ÜíH /Y(‚àë f(f *U√óA),‚àë fB)  ‚âÉFrob.Rec.H /Y(U√ó‚àë fA,‚àë fB)  ‚âÉH /Y(U,[‚àë fA,‚àë fB])
  \begin{aligned}
     \mathbf{H}_{/Y}( U, \prod_f [A,B] )
     & \simeq
     \mathbf{H}_{/X}( f^* U, [A,B] )
     \\
     & \simeq
     \mathbf{H}_{/X}(f^* U \times A, B)
     \\
     & \stackrel{}{\to}
    \mathbf{H}_{/Y}( \sum_f( f^* U \times A ), \sum_f B )
    \\
     & \stackrel{Frob.Rec.}{\simeq}
     \mathbf{H}_{/Y}( U \times \sum_f A , \sum_f B )
     \\
     & \simeq
    \mathbf{H}_{/Y}(U, [\sum_f A , \sum_f B])
  \end{aligned}


where the first and the last steps use adjunction properties, where the morphism in the middle is the component of the dependent sum functor, and where ‚ÄúFrob.Rec.‚Äù is Frobenius reciprocity.
Since this is natural in UU, the Yoneda lemma implies the claimed morphism.


Proof/Construction 2
There is the composite morphism
(f *‚àè f[A,B])√óA‚Üícounit√óid A[A,B]√óA‚ÜíevalB‚Üíunitf *‚àë fB
  \left(f^\ast \prod_f [A, B]\right) \times A \stackrel{counit \times id_A}{\to} [A, B] \times A \stackrel{eval}{\to} B \stackrel{unit}{\to} f^\ast \sum_f B

of the adjunction (co)units and the evaluation map of the internal hom. Its hom-adjunct is
A‚Üí[f *‚àè f[A,B],f *‚àë fB]‚âÖf *[‚àè f[A,B],‚àë fB],
  A \to [f^\ast \prod_f [A, B], f^\ast \sum_f B] \cong f^\ast [\prod_f [A, B], \sum_f B]
  \,,


using prop.  on the right. The hom-adjunct of that in turn is
‚àë fA‚Üí[‚àè f[A,B],‚àë fB]\sum_f A \to [\prod_f [A, B], \sum_f B]
and by symmetry the morphism that we are after:
‚àè f[A,B]‚Üí[‚àë fA,‚àë fB].
  \prod_f [A, B] \to [\sum_f A, \sum_f B]
  \,.



Remark
If YY is the terminal object (for simplicity), then the morphism of prop.  can be understood as follows: a global element of the dependent product ‚àè f[A,B]\prod_f [A,B] is given by a commuting diagram in H\mathbf{H} of the form
‚àë fA  ‚Üí  ‚àë fB  ‚Üò  ‚Üô   X.
  \array{
    \sum_f A &&\to&& \sum_f B
    \\
     & \searrow && \swarrow
     \\
     && X
  }
  \,.


The map in prop.  picks out the top horizontal morphism in this diagram.

For smooth spaces and smooth ‚àû\infty-groupoids
Consider the site C=C =  SmthMfd of smooth manifolds (and the open cover coverage) or equivalently over the dense subsite CartSp of Cartesian spaces and smooth functions between these.
The sheaf topos/(‚àû,1)-sheaf (‚àû,1)-topos H=Sh(C)\mathbf{H} = Sh(C) is that of smooth spaces/smooth ‚àû-groupoids. So the discussion of internal homs here is a special case of the above discussion In a sheaf topos.

Example
For X,Y‚ààSmthMfd‚Ü™HX , Y \in SmthMfd \hookrightarrow \mathbf{H} two smooth manifolds, the internal hom [X,Y]‚ààH[X,Y] \in \mathbf{H} is the mapping space between them regarded as a diffeological space.
See at manifold structure of mapping spaces for when this internal hom is representable again by a smooth manifold.


Example
For X‚ààSmthMfd‚Ü™HX \in SmthMfd \hookrightarrow \mathbf{H} the internal automorphism group, example , of XX is the diffeomorphism group of XX, regarded as a diffeological group
Aut(X)=Diff(X).
  \mathbf{Aut}(X) = \mathbf{Diff}(X)

For super vector spaces
The category sVectsVect of super vector spaces is the category of ‚Ñ§/2\mathbb{Z}/2-graded vector spaces. Thus, its objects are pairs of vector spaces (V +,V ‚àí)(V_+,V_-), with V +V_+ called the even part and V ‚àíV_- the odd part. The morphisms in sVectsVect are likewise pairs of linear maps, i.e. we define sVectsVect to be Vect√óVect=Vect ‚Ñ§/2Vect \times Vect = Vect^{\mathbb{Z}/2}, as usual for any sort of graded object. With this definition of the category sVectsVect, we capture the concepts of superalgebra and so on in succinct categorical terms.
Because the morphisms in sVectsVect send even things to even things and odd things to odd things, they are sometimes called even linear maps, and one may write
sVect(V,W)=EvenLin(V,W).
 sVect(V, W) = Even Lin(V,W).


Note that sVectsVect is enriched over VectVect, i.e. these hom-sets are vector spaces.
Occasionally, however, one does need to refer to the odd linear maps, which send even things to odd things and odd things to even things. That is, an odd linear map V‚ÜíWV\to W is a pair of linear maps V +‚ÜíW ‚àíV_+ \to W_- and V ‚àí‚ÜíW +V_-\to W_+. The internal-hom in sVectsVect allows us to capture these as well: it is the following super vector space:
[V,W] +=EvenLin(V,W)[V,W] ‚àí=OddLin(V,W).
  [V,W]_+ = Even Lin(V,W) \qquad
  [V,W]_- = Odd Lin(V,W).


With this definition, sVectsVect becomes a closed monoidal category.
We can equivalently regard a super vector spaces (V +,V ‚àí)(V_+,V_-) as being the direct sum vector space V +‚äïV ‚àíV_+ \oplus V_- equipped with this direct sum decomposition. If we view the internal-hom [V,W][V,W] in this way as well, then we have
[V,W]=EvenLin(V,W)‚äïOddLin(V,W)=Lin(V,W).
 [V, W] = Even Lin(V,W) \oplus Odd Lin(V,W) = Lin(V,W).


In other words, any linear map between these ‚Äúsummed‚Äù super vector spaces decomposes uniquely as the sum of an even linear map and an odd one.
For Banach spaces
A similar thing happens in the category BanBan of Banach spaces and short linear operators. The external hom consists of only the short linear maps (those bounded by 11):
Ban(V,W)={f:Lin(V,W)|‚Äñf‚Äñ‚â§1}. Ban(V,W) = \{ f\colon Lin(V,W) \;|\; {\|f\|} \leq 1 \} .
This definition of morphism recovers the most specific notion of isomorphism of Banach spaces, as well as defining the product and coproduct as the direct sum completed with p=‚àûp = \infty or p=1p = 1 respectively.
But the internal hom is the Banach space of all bounded linear maps:
[V,W]={f:Lin(V,W)|‚Äñf‚Äñ<‚àû}. [V,W] = \{ f\colon Lin(V,W) \;|\; {\|f\|} \lt \infty \} .
This is a Banach space and makes BanBan into a closed category.
Explicitly
A section of a morphism f:A‚ÜíBf : A \to B in some category is a right-inverse: a morphism œÉ:B‚ÜíA\sigma : B \to A such that
f‚àòœÉ:B‚ÜíœÉA‚ÜífB
  f \circ \sigma : B \stackrel{\sigma}{\to} A \stackrel{f}{\to} B


equals the identity morphism on BB.
Typically A‚ÜífBA \stackrel{f}{\to} B is thought of as a bundle and then one speaks of sections of bundles. For topological bundles one considers continuous sections, for smooth bundles smooth sections, etc.
In terms of dependent product
In a locally cartesian closed category ùíû\mathcal{C}, regard the morphism f:A‚ÜíBf\colon A \to B as an object [f]‚ààùíû /B[f] \in \mathcal{C}_{/B} in the slice category over BB. Then there is the dependent product
‚àèB[f]‚ààùíû.
  \underset{B}{\prod} [f] \in \mathcal{C}
  \,.


This is the space of sections of ff. A single section œÉ\sigma is a global element in here
œÉ:*‚Üí‚àèB[f].
  \sigma \colon \ast \to \underset{B}{\prod} [f]
  \,.


See at dependent product ‚Äì In terms of spaces of sections for more on this.
A natural topology on mapping spaces of continuous functions, important because of its role in exhibiting locally compact topological spaces to be exponentiable, as demonstrated below, culminating in Corollary .
The compact-open topology on the set of continuous functions X‚ÜíYX \to Y is generated by the subbasis of subsets U K‚äÇC(X,Y)U^K \subset C(X,Y) that map a given compact subspace K‚äÇXK \subset X to a given open subset U‚äÇYU \subset Y, whence the name.
When restricting to continuous functions between compactly generated topological spaces one usually modifies this definition to a subbase of open subsets U œï(K)U^{\phi(K)}, where now œï(K)\phi(K) is the image of a compact topological space under any continuous function œï:K‚ÜíX\phi \colon K \to X. This definition gives a cartesian internal hom in the category of compactly generated topological spaces (see also at convenient category of topological spaces).
The two definitions agree when the domain XX is a compactly generated Hausdorff space, but not in general. Beware that texts on compactly generated spaces nevertheless commonly say ‚Äúcompact-open topology‚Äù for the second definition.

Notation
Let (X,ùí™ X)(X, \mathcal{O}_{X}) and (Y,ùí™ Y)(Y, \mathcal{O}_{Y}) be topological spaces. We denote by Y XY^{X} the set of continuous maps from (X,ùí™ X)(X,\mathcal{O}_{X}) to (Y,ùí™ Y)(Y, \mathcal{O}_{Y}).


Remark
Other common notations for Y XY^{X} are Map(X,Y)Map(X,Y) or C(X,Y)C(X,Y).


Notation
Let (X,ùí™ X)(X, \mathcal{O}_{X}) be a topological space. We denote by ùí™ X c\mathcal{O}^{c}_{X} the set of subsets of XX which are compact with respect to ùí™ X\mathcal{O}_{X}.


Notation
Let (X,ùí™ X)(X, \mathcal{O}_{X}) be a topological space. Let AA be a subset of XX. We denote by A¬Ø\overline{A} the topological closure of AA in XX with respect to ùí™ X\mathcal{O}_{X}.


Definition
A topological space (X,ùí™ X)(X, \mathcal{O}_{X}) is locally compact if the set of compact neighbourhoods of points of XX form a neighbourhood basis of XX. That is to say: for every x‚ààXx \in X and every neighbourhood NN of xx, there is a V‚ààùí™ X cV \in \mathcal{O}^{c}_{X} and a U‚ààùí™ XU \in \mathcal{O}_{X} such that x‚ààU‚äÇV‚äÇNx \in U \subset V \subset N.


Remark
There are many variations on this definition, which can be found at locally compact space. These are all equivalent if (X,ùí™ X)(X, \mathcal{O}_{X}) is Hausdorff. We do not however make the assumption that (X,ùí™ X)(X, \mathcal{O}_{X}) is Hausdorff.


Notation
Let (X,ùí™ X)(X, \mathcal{O}_{X}) and (Y,ùí™ Y)(Y, \mathcal{O}_{Y}) be topological spaces. Given A‚ààùí™ X cA \in \mathcal{O}^{c}_{X} and U‚ààùí™ YU \in \mathcal{O}_{Y}, we denote by M A,UM_{A,U} the set of continuous maps f:X‚ÜíYf : X \rightarrow Y such that f(A)‚äÇUf(A) \subset U.


Definition
Let (X,ùí™ X)(X, \mathcal{O}_{X}) and (Y,ùí™ Y)(Y, \mathcal{O}_{Y}) be topological spaces. The compact-open topology on Y XY^{X} is that with sub-basis given by the set of sets M A,UM_{A,U} such that A‚ààùí™ X cA \in \mathcal{O}^{c}_{X} and U‚ààùí™ YU \in \mathcal{O}_{Y}.


Notation
Let (X,ùí™ X)(X, \mathcal{O}_{X}) and (Y,ùí™ Y)(Y, \mathcal{O}_{Y}) be topological spaces. We shall denote the compact-open topology (def. ) on Y XY^{X} by ùí™ Y X\mathcal{O}_{Y^{X}}.

Explicitly
A section of a morphism f:A‚ÜíBf : A \to B in some category is a right-inverse: a morphism œÉ:B‚ÜíA\sigma : B \to A such that
f‚àòœÉ:B‚ÜíœÉA‚ÜífB
  f \circ \sigma : B \stackrel{\sigma}{\to} A \stackrel{f}{\to} B


equals the identity morphism on BB.
Typically A‚ÜífBA \stackrel{f}{\to} B is thought of as a bundle and then one speaks of sections of bundles. For topological bundles one considers continuous sections, for smooth bundles smooth sections, etc.
In terms of dependent product
In a locally cartesian closed category ùíû\mathcal{C}, regard the morphism f:A‚ÜíBf\colon A \to B as an object [f]‚ààùíû /B[f] \in \mathcal{C}_{/B} in the slice category over BB. Then there is the dependent product
‚àèB[f]‚ààùíû.
  \underset{B}{\prod} [f] \in \mathcal{C}
  \,.


This is the space of sections of ff. A single section œÉ\sigma is a global element in here
œÉ:*‚Üí‚àèB[f].
  \sigma \colon \ast \to \underset{B}{\prod} [f]
  \,.


See at dependent product ‚Äì In terms of spaces of sections for more on this.
For ùíû\mathcal{C} a category and X,Y‚ààùíûX, Y \in \mathcal{C} two objects, the internal hom [X,Y]‚ààùíû[X,Y] \in \mathcal{C} from XX to YY is, if it exists, another object of ùíû\mathcal{C} which behaves like the ‚Äúobject of morphisms‚Äù from XX to YY. In other words it is, if it exists, an internal version of the ordinary hom set ùíû(X,Y)‚ààSet\mathcal{C}(X, Y) \in Set or more generally hom object ùíû(X,Y)‚ààùí±\mathcal{C}(X, Y) \in \mathcal{V} of a locally small category or ùí±\mathcal{V}-enriched category.
One way to make this precise starts by mimicking a property of the function set [X,Y]={f:X‚ÜíY}[X,Y] = \{f : X \to Y\} of functions between two sets XX and YY: this set is characterized by the fact that for any other set SS, the functions S‚Üí[X,Y]S \to [X,Y] are in natural bijection with the functions S√óX‚ÜíYS \times X \to Y out of the cartesian product of SS with XX. That is: for each set XX, the functor (‚àí)√óX(-) \times X has a right adjoint, given by the construction [X,‚àí][X,-].
One can verbalize this thus: taking the cartesian product with the set XX is left-adjoint to taking the set of all functions with domain XX.
This, then, is, generally, the definition of internal hom in any cartesian monoidal category or in fact in any monoidal category (ùíû,‚äó)(\mathcal{C}, \otimes): the right adjoint [X,‚àí][X,-] to the given tensor product functor (‚àí)‚äóX(-)\otimes X for all objects XX. It may or may not exist. If it exists, one says that (ùíû,‚äó)(\mathcal{C}, \otimes) is a closed monoidal category. Explicity, the condition is that there is an isomorphism(bijection)
ùíû(A,[X,Z])‚Üí‚âÉùíû(A‚äóX,Z)
  \mathcal{C}(A, [X,Z]) \stackrel{\simeq}{\to} \mathcal{C}(A \otimes X, Z)


which is natural in all three variables. (The rightward map here is often called currying, especially in a closed monoidal category (and more especially for the Œª\lambda-calculus).)
In particular this implies that in a closed monoidal category the external hom is re-obtained from the internal hom as its set of generalized elements out of the tensor unit I‚ààùíûI \in \mathcal{C} in that
I‚Üí[X,Y]X‚ÜíY
  \frac{I \to [X,Y]}{X \to Y}


using that I‚äóX‚âÉXI \otimes X \simeq X by definition of the tensor unit.
Here ‚Äúclosed‚Äù in ‚Äúclosed monoidal category‚Äù is in the sense that forming ‚Äúhom-sets‚Äù does not lead ‚Äúout of the category‚Äù. In fact the internal hom of a cartesian monoidal category is indeed the hom as seen in the internal logic of that category (the function type).
More generally, one can consider objects that satisfy some basic universal properties that an internal hom should satisfy even in the absence of a monoidal structure. If such objects exist one speaks therefore just of a closed category. Every closed category may be seen as a category enriched over itself. Accordingly, an internal hom is after all a special case of a hom-object, for the special case of this enrichment over itself.

Definition
(internal hom)
Let (ùíû,‚äó)(\mathcal{C}, \otimes) be a symmetric monoidal category. An internal hom in ùíû\mathcal{C} is a functor
[‚àí,‚àí]:ùíû op√óùíû‚Üíùíû
  [-,-] : \mathcal{C}^{op} \times \mathcal{C} \to \mathcal{C}


such that for every object X‚ààùíûX \in \mathcal{C} we have a pair of adjoint functors
((‚àí)‚äóX‚ä£[X,‚àí]):ùíû‚Üíùíû.
  ((-) \otimes X \dashv [X, -]) : \mathcal{C} \to \mathcal{C}
  \,.


If this exists, (ùíû,‚äó)(\mathcal{C}, \otimes) is called a closed monoidal category.


Remark
If the monoidal category ùíû\mathcal{C} in Def.  is not symmetric, there is instead a concept of left- and right-internal hom.

Evaluation map
Let (ùíû,‚äó)(\mathcal{C}, \otimes) be a symmetric closed monoidal category (Def. ).

Definition
For X,Y‚ààùíûX,Y \in \mathcal{C} two objects, the evaluation map
eval X,Y:[X,Y]‚äóX‚ÜíY
  eval_{X,Y} : [X,Y] \otimes X \to Y


is the ((‚àí)‚äóX‚ä£[X,‚àí])((-)\otimes X \dashv [X,-])-adjunct of the identity id [X,Y]:[X,Y]‚Üí[X,Y]id_{[X,Y]} : [X,Y] \to [X,Y].


Remark
If ùíû\mathcal{C} is specifically a locally cartesian closed category, then in terms of the type theory internal language of ùíû\mathcal{C} the evaluation map is the categorical semantics of the dependent type which in type theory syntax is
f:X‚ÜíY,x:X‚ä¢f(x):Y,
  f \colon X \to Y,\; x \colon X 
    \;\vdash\; 
   f(x) \colon Y
  \,,


with function application on the right.

Composition map
Let (ùíû,√ó)(\mathcal{C}, \times) be a symmetric closed monoidal category (Def. )

Definition
For X,Y,Z‚ààùíûX, Y, Z \in \mathcal{C} three objects, the composition morphism
‚àò X,Y,Z:[Y,Z]√ó[X,Y]‚Üí[X,Z]
  \circ_{X,Y,Z} : 
  [Y, Z]
  \times
  [X, Y]
  \to 
  [X, Z]


is the ((‚àí)√óX‚ä£[X,‚àí])((-)\times X \dashv [X,-])-adjunct of the following composite of two evaluation maps, def. :
[Y,Z]√ó[X,Y]√óX‚Üí(id [Y,Z],eval X,Y)[Y,Z]√óY‚Üíeval Y,ZZ.
  [Y, Z] \times [X , Y] \times X 
    \stackrel{(id_{[Y,Z]}, eval_{X,Y})}{\to}
  [Y,Z] \times Y
    \stackrel{eval_{Y,Z}}{\to}
  Z
  \,.


Basic properties
The internal homs in a symmetric closed monoidal category (Def. ) happen to share all the key abstract properties of ordinary (‚Äúexternal‚Äù) hom-functors, even though this is not completely manifest from Def. :

Proposition
(internal hom bifunctor)
Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a symmetric monoidal category such that for each object X‚ààùíûX \in \mathcal{C} the functor X‚äó(‚àí)X \otimes (-) has a right adjoint [X,‚àí][X,-]. Then this is already equivalent to Def. , in that there is a unique functor out of the product categoryof ùíû\mathcal{C} with its opposite category
[‚àí,‚àí]:ùíû op√óùíû‚ü∂ùíû
  [-,-]
  \;\colon\;
  \mathcal{C}^{op} \times \mathcal{C}
    \longrightarrow
  \mathcal{C}


such that for each X‚ààùíûX \in \mathcal{C} it coincides with the internal hom [X,‚àí][X,-] as a functor in the second variable, and such that there is a natural isomorphism
Hom(X,[Y,Z])‚âÉHom(X‚äóY,Z)
  Hom(X, [Y,Z])
  \;\simeq\;
  Hom(X \otimes Y, Z)


which is natural not only in XX and ZZ, but also in YY.


Proof
We have a natural isomorphism for each fixed YY, and hence in particular for fixed YY and fixed ZZ. With this the statement follows directly by this prop. at adjoint functor.

In fact the 3-variable adjunction from Prop.  even holds internally:

Proposition
(internal tensor/hom-adjunction)
In a closed monoidal category (def. ) there are natural isomorphisms
[X‚äóY,Z]‚âÉ[X,[Y,Z]]
  [X \otimes Y, Z]
   \;\simeq\;
  [X, [Y,Z]]


whose image under Hom ùíû(1,‚àí)Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(1,-) are the defining natural bijections of Prop. .


Proof
Let A‚ààùíûA \in \mathcal{C} be any object. By applying the natural bijections from Prop. , there are composite natural bijections
Hom ùíû(A,[X‚äóY,Z]) ‚âÉHom ùíû(A‚äó(X‚äóY),Z)  ‚âÉHom ùíû((A‚äóX)‚äóY,Z)  ‚âÉHom ùíû(A‚äóX,[Y,Z])  ‚âÉHom ùíû(A,[X,[Y,Z]])
  \begin{aligned}
    Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(A , [X \otimes Y, Z])
    & \simeq
    Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(A \otimes (X \otimes Y), Z)
    \\
    & \simeq
    Hom_{\mathcal{C}}((A \otimes X)\otimes Y, Z)
    \\
    & \simeq
    Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(A \otimes X, [Y,Z])
    \\
    & \simeq
    Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(A, [X, [Y,Z]])
  \end{aligned}


Since this holds for all AA, the fully faithfulness of the Yoneda embedding says that there is an isomorphism [X‚äóY,Z]‚âÉ[X,[Y,Z]][ X\otimes Y, Z ] \simeq [X, [Y,Z]]. Moreover, by taking A=1A = 1 in the above and using the left unitor isomorphisms A‚äó(X‚äóY)‚âÉX‚äóYA \otimes (X \otimes Y) \simeq X \otimes Y and A‚äóX‚âÉXA\otimes X \simeq X we get a commuting diagram
Hom ùíû(1,[X‚äóY,Z]) ‚ü∂‚âÉ Hom ùíû(1,[X,[Y,Z]])  ‚âÉ‚Üì  ‚Üì ‚âÉ Hom ùíû(X‚äóY,Z) ‚ü∂‚âÉ Hom ùíû(X,[Y,Z]).
  \array{
    Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(1, [X\otimes Y, Z ])
      &\overset{\simeq}{\longrightarrow}&
    Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(1, [X, [Y,Z]])
    \\
    {}^{\mathllap{\simeq}}\downarrow
      &&
    \downarrow^{\mathrlap{\simeq}}
    \\
    Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(X \otimes Y, Z)
     &\overset{\simeq}{\longrightarrow}&
    Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(X, [Y,Z])
  }
  \,.


Also the key respect of hom-functors for limits is inherited by internal hom-functors:

Proposition
(internal hom-functor preserves limits)
Let ùíû\mathcal{C} be a symmetric closed monoidal category with internal hom-bifunctor [‚àí,‚àí][-,-] (Prop. ). Then this bifunctor preserves limits in the second variable, and sends colimits in the first variable to limits:
[X,lim‚üµj‚ààùí•Y(j)]‚âÉlim‚üµj‚ààùí•[X,Y(j)]
  [X, \underset{\underset{j \in \mathcal{J}}{\longleftarrow}}{\lim} Y(j)]
  \;\simeq\;
  \underset{\underset{j \in \mathcal{J}}{\longleftarrow}}{\lim} [X, Y(j)]


and
[lim‚ü∂j‚ààùí•Y(j),X]‚âÉlim‚üµj‚ààùí•[Y(j),X]
  [\underset{\underset{j \in \mathcal{J}}{\longrightarrow}}{\lim} Y(j),X]
  \;\simeq\;
  \underset{\underset{j \in \mathcal{J}}{\longleftarrow}}{\lim} [Y(j),X]  



Proof
For X‚ààùíûX \in \mathcal{C} any object, [X,‚àí][X,-] is a right adjoint by definition, and hence preserves limits by adjoints preserve (co-)limits.
For the other case, let Y:‚Ñí‚ÜíùíûY \;\colon\; \mathcal{L} \to \mathcal{C} be a diagram in ùíû\mathcal{C}, and let C‚ààùíûC \in \mathcal{C} be any object. Then there are isomorphisms
Hom ùíû(C,[lim‚ü∂j‚ààùí•Y(j),X]) ‚âÉHom ùíû(C‚äólim‚ü∂j‚ààùí•Y(j),X)  ‚âÉHom ùíû(lim‚ü∂j‚ààùí•(C‚äóY(j)),X)  ‚âÉlim‚üµj‚ààùí•Hom ùíû((C‚äóY(j)),X)  ‚âÉlim‚üµj‚ààùí•Hom ùíû(C,[Y(j),X])  ‚âÉHom ùíû(C,lim‚üµj‚ààùí•[Y(j),X])
  \begin{aligned}
    Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(C, [ \underset{\underset{j \in \mathcal{J}}{\longrightarrow}}{\lim} Y(j), X ] )
    & \simeq
    Hom_{\mathcal{C}}( C \otimes \underset{\underset{j \in \mathcal{J}}{\longrightarrow}}{\lim} Y(j), X )
    \\
    & \simeq
    Hom_{\mathcal{C}}( \underset{\underset{j \in \mathcal{J}}{\longrightarrow}}{\lim} (C \otimes Y(j)), X )   
    \\
    & \simeq
    \underset{\underset{j \in \mathcal{J}}{\longleftarrow}}{\lim}
    Hom_{\mathcal{C}}( (C \otimes Y(j)), X )    
    \\
    & \simeq
    \underset{\underset{j \in \mathcal{J}}{\longleftarrow}}{\lim}
    Hom_{\mathcal{C}}( C, [Y(j), X] )    
    \\
    & \simeq
    Hom_{\mathcal{C}}( C, \underset{\underset{j \in \mathcal{J}}{\longleftarrow}}{\lim} [Y(j), X] )    
  \end{aligned}


which are natural in C‚ààùíûC \in \mathcal{C}, where we used that the ordinary hom-functor respects (co)limits as shown (see at hom-functor preserves limits), and that the left adjoint C‚äó(‚àí)C \otimes (-) preserves colimits (see at adjoints preserve (co-)limits).
Hence by the fully faithfulness of the Yoneda embedding, there is an isomorphism
[lim‚ü∂j‚ààùí•Y(j),X]‚ü∂‚âÉlim‚üµj‚ààùí•[Y(j),X].
  \left[ \underset{\underset{j \in \mathcal{J}}{\longrightarrow}}{\lim} Y(j), X \right]  
  \overset{\simeq}{\longrightarrow}
  \underset{\underset{j \in \mathcal{J}}{\longleftarrow}}{\lim} [Y(j), X] 
  \,.


Relation to function types
The internal hom is the categorical semantics of what in type theory are function types

natural deductionuniversal construction

Induced monad (state monad)
For each object SS the (internal hom ‚ä£\dashv tensor product)-adjunction induces a monad [S,S‚äó(‚àí)][S, S \otimes (-)]. In computer science this monad (in computer science) is called the state monad.
Stable splitting
In topology the stabilization/suspension spectrum Œ£ ‚àûMaps(X,A)\Sigma^\infty  Maps(X,A) of mapping spaces Maps(X,A)Maps(X,A) between suitable CW-complexes X,AX, A happens to decompose as a direct sum of spectra in a useful way, related to the expression of the Goodwillie derivatives of the functor Maps(X,‚àí)Maps(X,-).
For more on this see at stable splitting of mapping spaces.
In sets
In the category Set of sets, regarded as a cartesian monoidal category, the internal hom is given by function sets. This exists, by the discussion there, as soon as the foundational axioms are strong enough, for instance as soon as there are power objects, which is the special case of a function set into the 2-element set.
In simplicial sets
In the category sSet of simplicial sets, the internal hom between two simplicial sets X,YX,Y is given by the formula
[X,Y] n=Hom sSet(X√óŒî[n],Y),
  [X,Y]_n = Hom_{sSet}(X\times \Delta[n],Y)
  \,,


where Œî[n]\Delta[n] is the simplicial n-simplex. This [X,Y]‚ààsSet[X,Y] \in sSet is also called the function complex between XX and YY.
Since sSet‚âÉPSh(Œî)sSet \simeq PSh(\Delta) is the category of presheaves over the simplex category, this is a special case of internal homs in sheaf toposes, discussed below.
In a sheaf topos or (‚àû,1)(\infty,1)-sheaf (‚àû,1)(\infty,1)-topos
Let CC be a site. Let H=Sh(C)\mathbf{H} = Sh(C) be the sheaf topos over CC or in fact the (‚àû,1)-sheaf (‚àû,1)-topos. We discuss the internal hom of this regard as a cartesian monoidal category/cartesian monoidal (‚àû,1)-category.

Proposition
The sheaf topos H\mathbf{H} is a cartesian closed category / cartesian closed (‚àû,1)-category. In fact it is a locally cartesian closed category / locally cartesian closed (‚àû,1)-category.

Hence the internal hom exist.

Proposition
For X,Y‚ààHX, Y \in \mathbf{H} two objects, the internal hom-object
[X,Y]‚ààH
  [X,Y] \in \mathbf{H}


is the sheaf/(‚àû,1)-sheaf given by the assignment
[X,Y]:U‚Ü¶H(U√óX,Y),
  [X,Y] : U \mapsto \mathbf{H}(U \times X, Y)
  \,,


for all objects U‚ààCU \in C which on the right we regard under the Yoneda embedding/‚àû-Yoneda embedding U‚ààC‚Ü™YonedaHU \in C \stackrel{Yoneda}{\hookrightarrow} \mathbf{H}.
Here


U√óX‚ààHU \times X \in \mathbf{H} is the cartesian product of UU with XX


H(‚àí,‚àí)\mathbf{H}(-,-) is the hom set-functor / hom space-(‚àû,1)-functor of H\mathbf{H}.



See also at closed monoidal structure on presheaves.

Proof
By the Yoneda lemma/(‚àû,1)-Yoneda lemma we have natural equivalences
[X,Y](U)‚âÉH(U,[X,Y])
  [X,Y](U) \simeq \mathbf{H}(U , [X,Y])


and by the defining ((‚àí)√óX‚ä¢[X,‚àí])((-)\times X \vdash [X,-])adjunction this is naturally equivalent to
‚ãØ‚âÉH(U√óX,Y).
  \cdots \simeq \mathbf{H}(U \times X, Y)
  \,.



Remark
In the (homotopy-)type theory syntax of the internal language of H\mathbf{H} the internal hom [X,Y]‚ààH[X, Y] \in \mathbf{H} is the categorical semantics of the function type
‚ä¢(X‚ÜíY):Type.
  \vdash (X \to Y) : Type
  \,.



Proposition
For X,Y‚ààHX, Y \in \mathbf{H}, the evaluation map, def. ,
eval X,Y:[X,Y]√óX‚ÜíY
  eval_{X,Y} : [X,Y] \times X \to Y


is the morphism of sheaves which over each U‚ààCU \in C sends a morphism of sheaves Œ∏:H(‚àí,U)√óX(‚àí)‚ÜíY(‚àí)\theta : \mathbf{H}(-,U) \times X(-) \to Y(-) (which is the first component by prop. ) and an x‚ààH(U,X)x \in \mathbf{H}(U,X) to
eval X,Y(U):(Œ∏,x)‚Ü¶Œ∏ U(id U,x)‚ààY(U).
  eval_{X,Y}(U) : (\theta, x) \mapsto \theta_U(id_U, x) \in Y(U)
  \,.


See (MacLane-Moerdijk, p. 46).

Proposition
For X,Y,Z‚ààHX, Y, Z \in \mathbf{H} three objects of H\mathbf{H}, the canonical composition morphism, def. ,
‚àò X,Y,Z:[Y,Z]√ó[X,Y]‚Üí[X,Z]
  \circ_{X,Y,Z} : 
  [Y, Z] \times [X, Y] \to [X, Z]


is given by the morphism of presheaves/(‚àû,1)-presheaves whose component over U‚ààCU \in C is the morphism of sets/‚àû-groupoids
‚àò X,Y,Z(U):H(U√óX,Y)√óH(U√óY,Z)‚ÜíH(U√óX,Z)
  \circ_{X,Y,Z}(U)
  : 
  \mathbf{H}(U \times X, Y)
  \times
  \mathbf{H}(U \times Y, Z)
  \to 
  \mathbf{H}(U \times X, Z)


which sends a pair (f:U√óX‚ÜíY,g:U√óY‚ÜíZ)(f : U \times X \to Y, g : U \times Y \to Z) to the composite
‚àò X,Y,Z(U)(f,g)=U√óX‚Üí(Œî U,id X)U√óU√óX‚Üí(id U,f)U√óY‚ÜígZ,
  \circ_{X,Y,Z}(U)(f,g)
  = 
  U \times X 
  \stackrel{(\Delta_U, id_X)}{\to}
  U \times U \times X
  \stackrel{(id_U, f)}{\to}
  U \times Y 
  \stackrel{g}{\to}
  Z
  \,,


where Œî U:U‚ÜíU√óU\Delta_U : U \to U \times U is the diagonal morphism on UU.


Proof
By definition  the morphism is the adjunct of the double evaluation map
[Y,Z]√ó[X,Y]√óX‚ÜíZ.
  [Y,Z] \times [X,Y] \times X \to Z
  \,.


Since the cartesian product of two sheaves A,B‚ààHA, B \in \mathbf{H} is computed objectwise
A√óB:U‚Ü¶A(U)√óB(U)
  A \times B : U \mapsto A(U) \times B(U)


it follows that over each U‚ààCU \in C this double evaluation map is the morphism of sets/‚àû\infty-groupoids
[Y,Z](U)√ó[X,Y](U)√óX(U)‚ÜíZ(U)
  [Y,Z](U) \times [X,Y](U) \times X(U) \to Z(U)


hence by prop. 
H(U√óY,Z)√óH(U√óX,Y)√óH(U,X)‚ÜíH(U,Z),
  \mathbf{H}(U \times Y, Z) \times \mathbf{H}(U \times X, Y) \times 
  \mathbf{H}(U,X) \to \mathbf{H}(U,Z)
  \,,


where now by prop.  this is the external evaluation.


Remark
Intuitively this says that the composite of a UU-parameterized family of maps {f(u):X‚ÜíY|u‚ààU}\{f(u) :  X \to Y| u \in U\} with a UU-parameterized family of maps g(u):Y‚ÜíZ|u‚ààU{g(u) : Y \to Z| u \in U} is the UU-family given by the parameter-wise composite {g(u)‚àòf(u)|u‚ààU}\{g(u)\circ f(u) | u \in U\}.


Example
The internal automorphism group/automorphism ‚àû-group of an object X‚ààHX \in \mathbf{H} is the subobject
Aut(X)‚Ü™[X,X]
  \mathbf{Aut}(X) \hookrightarrow [X,X]


of the internal hom which is maximal subject to the property that the composition of prop.  becomes invertible.
The (homotopy-)type theory syntax for this is given by the type of equivalences in homotopy type theory
‚ä¢(X‚Üí‚âÉX):Type.
  \vdash (X \stackrel{\simeq}{\to} X) : Type
  \,.


In slice categories
Let H\mathbf{H} be a locally cartesian closed category. This means that for each object X‚ààHX \in \mathbf{H} the slice category H /X\mathbf{H}_{/X} is a cartesian closed category. The product in the slice is given by the fiber product over XX computed in H\mathbf{H}. Fairly detailed discussion of constructions of the internal hom in such slices H /X\mathbf{H}_{/X} is at locally cartesian closed category ‚Äì cartesian closure in terms of base change and dependent product.
We record some further properties

Proposition
For ùíû\mathcal{C} a locally cartesian closed category and f:X‚ÜíYf \colon X \to Y any morphism in ùíû\mathcal{C}, the inverse image f *f^* of the corresponding base change adjunction
ùíû /X‚Üí‚àè f‚Üêf *‚Üí‚àë fùíû /Y
  \mathcal{C}_{/X}
   \stackrel{\overset{\sum_f}{\to}}{\stackrel{\overset{f^*}{\leftarrow}}{\underset{\prod_f}{\to}}}
  \mathcal{C}_{/Y}


is a cartesian closed functor.

This is discussed in more detail at cartesian closed functor ‚Äì Examples.
So for A,B‚ààùíû /YA,B \in \mathcal{C}_{/Y} we have isomorphisms
f *[A,B]‚Üí‚âÉ[f *A,f *B]
  f^* \left[A,B\right] \stackrel{\simeq}{\to} \left[f^* A , f^* B\right]


between the image of the internal hom under f *f^* and the internal hom of the images of AA and BB separately.

Proposition
For H\mathbf{H} a locally cartesian closed category, f:X‚ÜíYf \colon X \to Y any morphism, and A,B‚ààH /XA, B \in \mathbf{H}_{/X} two objects in the slice over XX, there is a natural morphism (not in general an isomorphism)
‚àè f[A,B]‚Üí[‚àë fA,‚àë fB].
  \prod_f \left[A,B \right] \to \left[ \sum_f A, \sum_f B\right]
  \,.


Here are two ways to get this morphism:

Proof/Construction 1
For any object U‚ààH /YU \in \mathbf{H}_{/Y} we have a canonical morphism of hom sets
H /Y(U,‚àè f[A,B]) ‚âÉH /X(f *U,[A,B])  ‚âÉH /X(f *U√óA,B)  ‚ÜíH /Y(‚àë f(f *U√óA),‚àë fB)  ‚âÉFrob.Rec.H /Y(U√ó‚àë fA,‚àë fB)  ‚âÉH /Y(U,[‚àë fA,‚àë fB])
  \begin{aligned}
     \mathbf{H}_{/Y}( U, \prod_f [A,B] )
     & \simeq
     \mathbf{H}_{/X}( f^* U, [A,B] )
     \\
     & \simeq
     \mathbf{H}_{/X}(f^* U \times A, B)
     \\
     & \stackrel{}{\to}
    \mathbf{H}_{/Y}( \sum_f( f^* U \times A ), \sum_f B )
    \\
     & \stackrel{Frob.Rec.}{\simeq}
     \mathbf{H}_{/Y}( U \times \sum_f A , \sum_f B )
     \\
     & \simeq
    \mathbf{H}_{/Y}(U, [\sum_f A , \sum_f B])
  \end{aligned}


where the first and the last steps use adjunction properties, where the morphism in the middle is the component of the dependent sum functor, and where ‚ÄúFrob.Rec.‚Äù is Frobenius reciprocity.
Since this is natural in UU, the Yoneda lemma implies the claimed morphism.


Proof/Construction 2
There is the composite morphism
(f *‚àè f[A,B])√óA‚Üícounit√óid A[A,B]√óA‚ÜíevalB‚Üíunitf *‚àë fB
  \left(f^\ast \prod_f [A, B]\right) \times A \stackrel{counit \times id_A}{\to} [A, B] \times A \stackrel{eval}{\to} B \stackrel{unit}{\to} f^\ast \sum_f B

of the adjunction (co)units and the evaluation map of the internal hom. Its hom-adjunct is
A‚Üí[f *‚àè f[A,B],f *‚àë fB]‚âÖf *[‚àè f[A,B],‚àë fB],
  A \to [f^\ast \prod_f [A, B], f^\ast \sum_f B] \cong f^\ast [\prod_f [A, B], \sum_f B]
  \,,


using prop.  on the right. The hom-adjunct of that in turn is
‚àë fA‚Üí[‚àè f[A,B],‚àë fB]\sum_f A \to [\prod_f [A, B], \sum_f B]
and by symmetry the morphism that we are after:
‚àè f[A,B]‚Üí[‚àë fA,‚àë fB].
  \prod_f [A, B] \to [\sum_f A, \sum_f B]
  \,.



Remark
If YY is the terminal object (for simplicity), then the morphism of prop.  can be understood as follows: a global element of the dependent product ‚àè f[A,B]\prod_f [A,B] is given by a commuting diagram in H\mathbf{H} of the form
‚àë fA  ‚Üí  ‚àë fB  ‚Üò  ‚Üô   X.
  \array{
    \sum_f A &&\to&& \sum_f B
    \\
     & \searrow && \swarrow
     \\
     && X
  }
  \,.


The map in prop.  picks out the top horizontal morphism in this diagram.

For smooth spaces and smooth ‚àû\infty-groupoids

Example

See at manifold structure of mapping spaces for when this internal hom is representable again by a smooth manifold.


Example
For X‚ààSmthMfd‚Ü™HX \in SmthMfd \hookrightarrow \mathbf{H} the internal automorphism group, example , of XX is the diffeomorphism group of XX, regarded as a diffeological group
Aut(X)=Diff(X).
  \mathbf{Aut}(X) = \mathbf{Diff}(X)
  \,.
